Ottawa,
February 4, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo enclosing Captain Barry's report of his recent inspection of the Katzle Indian Day School. I agree with your recommendation that the school should be inspected again about May or June and you will no doubt make the necessary arrangements in this regard with Inspector Barry.

After carefully considering the contents of Inspector Barry's report I am under the impression that we should dispense with the services of Miss Daly at the end of the current academic year unless Inspector Barry finds, on his next inspection, that there has been a very decided improvement both in the work and in the teacher's attitude toward it. In order to permit a month's notice being given to Miss Daly in the event of her dismissal it would be advisable to have the school inspected early in May.

I cannot agree that there is any advantage in reducing the length of the academic year at this school so drastically as suggested by Inspector Barry. Every endeavour should be made, however, to increase the attendance at this school.

Yours truly,

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

Ottawa, November 28, 1940.

Dear Mr. Cruickshank:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of November 20, in which you refer to a misunderstanding that appears to have arisen between Miss L. M. Dynes, clerk at the New Westminster Indian Agency, and Miss Maureen Daly, teacher at present in charge of the Katsie Indian Day School, Port Hammond, B. C.

The officials of the Indian Affairs Branch inform me that teachers in charge of Indian day and residential schools are encouraged to attend teachers' conventions wherever it is convenient for them to do so. It is usual, however, for our teachers to secure written permission from Indian agents before abandoning their schools. It is just possible that Miss Daly, being a recently appointed teacher, failed to secure the Indian agent's consent.

I can only express regret that this misunderstanding has arisen. It is my hope that the explanation I am sending forward will enable Miss Daly to secure the time necessary to attend any conventions she may care to attend in the future.

Yours sincerely,

W. J. F. PRATT

W. J. F. Pratt,

CONFIDENTIAL

Mr. W.J.F. Pratt,
Private Secretary to the
Minister of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA.

Dear Mr. Pratt:

Miss Maureen Daly, teacher at the Katsik Indian Day School, Hammond, B.C., closed her school for a day in order to attend a B.C. Teachers' convention, and Miss Dynes, stenographer at the Indian Agency Office at New Westminster, came to her school and demanded a written apology for the action in closing the school. Miss Daly refused to give this apology and apparently there is a great deal of friction over the matter.

Surely it is right for a teacher at an Indian Day School to attend a Teachers' Convention for a day and try to keep up with her work, particularly as I understand their appointment is merely temporary, and she may have to leave shortly to teach in the ordinary provincial schools.

Would you please advise me if it is contrary to the instructions of the Superintendent of Education for teachers in the Indian Department to attend an ordinary Teachers' Convention.

Yours very truly,

sgd) George Cruickshank

George Cruickshank, M.P.
Fraser Valley

Ottawa, March 31, 1941.

Dear Madam:

Your letter of the 24th instant, addressed to the Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, has been referred to this office for reply.

Under Treasury Board Minute No. 201265, of the 9th December, 1940, authority is given, effective January 1, 1941, for the deduction and transfer to the Province of British Columbia of 1½¢ from the salaries of all Dominion Government employees residing in British Columbia.

The salaries of unmarried persons are exempt from the above-noted to the extent of $600 per annum. Therefore in your case only $40 a month is taxable ($90 - $50) at 1½¢ = .40¢, the amount deducted from your salary from January 1, 1941.

Yours truly,

L.W. McCutcheon
Chief Treasury Officer.

Miss Maureen Daly,
Port Hammond,
B.C.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 12th instant and also a letter of resignation received by you from Miss Maureen Daly as teacher of the above-noted school.

It is noted that you have asked Archbishop Duke to nominate a teacher for the vacant position.

In this connection I have been wondering if any action could be taken to encourage teachers to give at least one month's notice when retiring from positions at our schools. We have been deluged with a large number of resignations recently and it is almost impossible for the Department to secure teachers at this comparatively late date. If teachers in charge of public schools acted in this way, their certificates would be immediately cancelled by the Department of Education. This is a matter you might well discuss with the provincial authorities during one of your visits to Victoria.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated September 5th, enclosing a copy of the resignation submitted by Miss Maureen Daly of her position as teacher at the Katzie Indian Day School.

This School, since it was opened in 1923, has been a difficult one to keep up to quota, and for the last two or three years the Department has paid for the operation of a ferry-boat from the south bank of the Fraser River, in order to assist in this direction. Even with this assistance, the average attendance has only been nine pupils. The children arriving at school age this summer will barely balance the discharges, so we cannot hope for any improvement in this condition. So far as attendance is concerned, therefore, I do not think this School warrants its continuation.

On the other hand, however, the question arises of what we are to do with this average of nine pupils? The St. Mary's Mission Indian Residential School is full to capacity and they cannot be taken in there. Langley Municipal Schools on the south shore, and Pitt Meadows, on the north shore of the Fraser, are not very conveniently situated for the Reserves, even if the local Authorities were willing to accept Indian children.

It would seem that if these children are to continue to receive an education, we have no option but to endeavour to get a new teacher and continue to operate the school for the time being.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

A.O.N. Daunt,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 17th instant, file 153-18-1, in connection with the resignation of Miss Maureen Daly as teacher of the Katzie Day School, I would advise that this teacher gave ample notice of her resignation, this being dated August 31st last. It was not immediately forwarded to the Department, however, as enquiries were being made of Mr. Indian Agent Daunt as to whether he considered it advisable to continue this school in operation, copy of his reply of the 6th instant being enclosed herewith.

The present difficulty of teachers resigning on short notice has been due to the demand for them in the various war services in the Province and in view of the grave shortage of teachers for Provincial Schools it is doubtful if the Provincial Department of Education would agree to cancel the certificates of our teachers who are resigning without giving sufficient notice. However, I will discuss the problem with Dr. Willis when I am next in Victoria.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Re- Katzie School.

The roof of the above named school is in need of repair. Although it has not functioned for several years, it nevertheless should be reshingled as it is leaking and if allowed to remain as is, the lining, ceiling and flooring will be damaged. An amount of $203.00 was placed in the current year's estimates for this work.

Jordan's, General Merchants at Port Hammond, had their building contractor make a survey, and their tender is attached for $232.40, plus $55.00 for paint work. Every window-pane in the building is broken. The cost of supplying the glass and glazing, will according to Jordan's cost $97.50.

These repairs may be held in abeyance, pending the reopening of the school. The windows are boarded up, and I think no further damage will be done.

The Indians of Katzie have requested that the school be reopened. I am gathering data as to the number of children etc., and will submit a report in the very near future.

J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.

REPORT ON NEW BRUNSWICK AGENCY FOR THE YEAR ENDING 1944-45.

Schools: Three day schools have been operated throughout the year, viz: Pemberton, Chehalis and Skwah. The fourth school at Katzic Reserve has remained closed, and the desks have been shipped to the Skeen Agency.

A. O'H. Daunt,
Indian Agent.
Repairs to Buildings - The only Departmentally owned buildings in the Agency are four day schools, viz:- Pemberton, Chehalis, Skwah and Katzic. These are all in fair repair, except Katzic. This latter school has been closed for two years, and most of the windows were broken by boys. We boarded them all up, so no further damage is possible. The roof is also in poor condition, and we stopped actual leaks with such material as was on hand. The desks were all shipped to Skeena Agency in January. Both Chehalis and Skwah schools should be painted and redecorated, but it is impossible to interest people in submitting tenders at the present time. When there is more work available in the cities and towns than can be attended to, no workmen are anxious to go out in the country on jobs. The buildings will really come to no harm until after the war, but they should certainly be attended to then.

A. O'N. Daunt,
Indian Agent.

Your File No.215-8-4814.

Attached hereto is a resolution of the Ketzie Band of Indians, requesting the establishment of their School.

I have made a survey of the number of children belonging to the Band, and my findings are on the enclosed list, for the years 1946 to 1952 inclusive.

I have recently canvassed the homes, and I doubt if it would be advisable to reopen the School for the following reasons:

1. Four parents only, comprising nine children pledged to send their children to School.
2. Four of the nine children would have to be transported daily by boat at a cost of $3.00.
3. Two children living on the Reserve on which the School is situated can attend a White School.
4. Ten children will be at the Canneries with their parents indefinitely.

I would recommend, therefore, that an expenditure of $287.40 for repairs to the roof only be authorized for the time being.

J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.

Katzie Indian Day School.

Ref. your 215-8-4890 of August 15, 1946.

The Department concurs in your recommendation that the above school should not be re-opened at the present time for the following reasons:

(a). Shortage of teachers
(b). More immediate need of teachers at other Indian schools with larger attendance in British Columbia.
(c). Small pupilage available in the vicinity of this school for regular attendance.

INDIAN DAY SCHOOL REGULATIONS

All Indian schools shall be kept open for not less than 200 days in each year.

Schools shall be opened after the summer holidays on September 1st, unless this date should be Labour Day, and shall close for Christmas holidays on December 22nd.

The winter term will commence on January 3rd and end on June 30th in each year.

The following holidays will be observed during the year—All Sundays, Labour Day, all King's Birthday, Canada Day, Easter Monday, the remaining day of the week following Easter Monday.

In addition to the above, the Roman Catholic schools will observe all holidays a limited number of holy days and for which payment of salary will be allowed, which will be arranged during the summer (two months) upon the recommendation of the local Agent, subject to the approval of the Superintendent.

When in the interest of the school work, it becomes necessary to declare a holiday, the decision shall be made by the head of the school, and the decision shall be made when the express approval of the Superintendent has been obtained.

The morning session shall be from 9 a.m. to 12 noon, and the afternoon session from 1 p.m. to 4 p.m., with recess during each session of not less than 15 and not more than 20 minutes.

Salaries of teachers will be paid on a basis of ten (10) teaching months in each school year.

Salaries will be paid at the end of each quarter, except in the quarterly return. As school is opened (or commenced), payments for the period for this quarter will be made; and thereafter each of the other quarters in the school year—a school is regularly taught—three months' salary will be paid at the end of the quarter.

Summer holidays are not taken into account in payment of yearly salaries. Each school year shall be regarded as the time mentioned above, and the yearly salary allowed therefor, as heretofore stated, special provisions being made for the classes mentioned above, and the yearly salary allowed therefor, as heretofore stated, special provisions being made for the classes mentioned above.

All teachers will be required to give at least one month's notice of their intention to resign.

All questions relating to the day school should be referred to the local Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6394, File 816-3, part 1)
Ottawa, January 8th, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo, enclosing a communication which you received from Miss Mabel Boeur, teacher of the Katzle Indian Day School, in which she requests an increase in salary in lieu of living quarters which are provided in the case of the other two teachers in your Agency.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will allow Miss Boeur an increase of $100 in her salary from the 1st instant. This will raise her salary from that date at the rate of $900 per annum, which will be supplemented by the bonus provided by law. This is the full amount that we can provide for a teacher's services at this school. Kindly inform Miss Boeur accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. O'N. Daunt, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
New Westminster,
B.C.

Ottawa, September 28, 1943.

Mr. A. O'N. Daunt, Indian agent, New Westminster, B.C.

The Stationery Office has forwarded to me S.D. No. 251524 on which you make the following notation "This school is not operating and supplies should not be sent unless requisitioned for". I agree with what you say but these special books were ordered by the Minister, and we were instructed to send them to all the schools. At the time these books were shipped we were hopeful that we would obtain a teacher for that school.

Of course, there is another side to the question, and that is, if we delay shipping the supplies for any schools until it is actually in operation, the teacher inevitably complains that she has no supplies to work with. As you know there is always a delay in shipping supplies from the Stationery Office to the schools in British Columbia and especially at the present time when materials are hard to obtain, and due to congested railways deliveries are uncertain.

As to the six books to which special reference is made you may either keep them until the Katzie school re-opens or send them to other schools in your agency which are in operation.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

The inside of the school should most certainly be rekalsomined. This has been recommended previously in my reports of February and November, 1932. From a health point of view, if from no other, this rekalsomining should be carried out during the summer vacation of this year, 1934.

The teacher has done her best to keep this school in a sanitary condition as reported last year. She even bought material herself to kalsomine the interior of the toilets, as has been previously reported.

Dear Major MacKay:

I have read Departmental letter 152-12-5 of November 19th last with reference to the proposed electric light installation at the Katzie Indian Day School, New Westminster Agency. I also visited the school yesterday for a routine inspection, and have discussed the matter with Mr. Indian Agent Daunt.

The B.C.Provincial Department of Education has never as far as I know discouraged the use of electric lighting in Provincial day schools; but on the other hand has encouraged its proper use in an effort to prevent harm to the eyes of the children attending such schools in such places as the electric light was available.

There would be only a very small expenditure for the replacement of electric light bulbs, of which only six are I find necessary. There should be four drop lights each of 150 watts in the schoolroom, one of 60 watts in the entrance hall and one of 60 watts over the porch.

Extra windows were placed in this school to improve the lighting, which they did, but on dull winter days the schoolroom is rather dark and there is a strain on the pupils' eyes in working from material on the boards.

The charge for connection to the B.C.Electric Power Lines is more or less nominal as in any case the lines will be passing very near the school house. One dollar a month minimum charge for current, itself very reasonable, would be the largest expense in connection with the proper lighting of this small school.

I would recommend that the electric light be installed as recommended by the Indian Agent.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
Ottawa,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 12th instant with reference to providing electricity in the Katzie Indian Day School.

I understand that some of the Provincial Departments of Education discourage the use of electric light in day schools. It increases the fire hazard and in addition there is generally a considerable expenditure for replacement of electric light bulbs.

I note from your letter that the Katzie School is inadequately lighted. Possibly something could be done to improve the school in this regard. Before deciding to install electricity I should appreciate it if you would give the matter further consideration and let me have your opinion.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hosy,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:-

The British Columbia Electric Railway Company are putting in a Light and Power line from the village of Hammond to Mr. Chatwin's farm, which lies to the west of the Katzie No. 1, Indian Reserve, upon which we maintain an Indian Day School.

This line passes a short distance from the school, and I was wondering whether the Department would care to take advantage of the fact, to provide satisfactory lighting in the building. Apart from the understood question of adequate light during the dark winter afternoons, this school is not particularly well lighted at any time, and I think Captain Barry will agree with me, that there are or will be, a number of ordinary winter days, when artificial light over the blackboards would be an advantage.

For your information, I checked up the cost of connection, with the B.C.Electric, and am told that this will amount to $125.00. This includes the line from the school to the Power Line right-of-way on the Dyke, nine lights in the school, being four on the blackboards, two in the school-room, one in the store-room, one in the hall-way, and one on the porch. The inside wiring would be done in conduit pipes, as is required in public buildings. Switches are also covered by the quotation.

The minimum charge for current would be $1.00 per month.

As this line had not been considered by the Company at the time our Estimates went in, I made no provision for such an expense, but am now bringing it to your attention, in case the Department may consider such service beneficial to the school, and well-being of the pupils.

Yours truly,

Dear Major MacKay:

I have read Mr. Daunt's letter 1-8-E dated October 28th last with reference to the provision of adequate lighting at the Katzle Indian Day School, New Westminster Agency.

I may say that I certainly do agree with Mr. Daunt that the above mentioned school is not well lighted at any time and particularly in winter, when it is quite difficult to make use of the Blackboards during the afternoon session.

The usual method of lighting a country schoolroom is by means of four drop lights placed some distance from each corner and about over the outside rows of desks. Such lights are better than any special lighting near the actual Blackboards, and the desk tops are thus properly illuminated.

May I suggest to Indian Agent Daunt and the Department that the provision of what is called SIGHT SAVING CHALK a new product in which a little yellow pigment is introduced into the ordinary hard blackboard crayon would make it much easier for the children to read the work on the Blackboards, particularly if the electric light is brought into the school.

I am very strongly in favour of the Indian Agent's suggestion that the above school be connected with the B.C.Electric mains and the light used by the teacher when necessary. The cost appears to me to be very reasonable.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry  
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

SIR:

I have just now received word from the teacher, that Adams has had no payment for January, February, and of course for March, and that he is giving up the service from April 5th, unless payment is received by that date. He has had to go in debt for his gasoline, and cannot carry on further.

TEACHER'S NAME, QUALIFICATIONS, SALARY, AGE, CONDITION, SUCCESS, SUGGESTIONS, ETC.

John Hinchey - 25 years. Page - no education - good, proposes marriage. Substitutes in Enniskillen. Teaching and writing. Delays 60 per month. In Enniskillen. He has taken his first deserted village. He went this year in arts at the Royal University. Arithmetic just received. Orphaned. No biography. Some good pupils. John is a bright and energetic boy. His pupils are active young men. He performs physical exercise. The teacher teaching them. The school is small and closed. We expect the pupils taking part in the exercises.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6394, File 816-6, part 1)
BUILDINGS AND PREMISES.

The school-room was an Indian house, cleared and opened. It has been thoroughly overhauled. Additional windows have been put in it. When completed it will be fairly comfortable.

Chimney & Indians working around the building at the time of my visit. They expected to finish the next day.

GENERAL REMARKS.

Two of the pupils were from Sycilis Boarding School. The parents want to have them in the Day School. I have also four pupils that have spent some time in St. Mary's Mission Boarding School. I was not able to discover whether these pupils had been discharged from Boarding schools or not, before enrollment. The Indians seem to be entirely interested in this school and say they will send their children regularly.

BUILDINGS AND PREMISES.

Indians were working at the building at the time of my previous visit, Oct. 29, but did not quite complete their work. No chimney was built. The stove was up and the pipe running yet in during in the same of the building. Urged the completion of the work.

There is a good playground surrounding the building.

TEACHER'S NAME, QUALIFICATIONS, SALARY, AGE, CONDITION, SUCCESS, SUGGESTIONS, ETC.

Miss Helen Coughlan.
She has a Third-class certificate with full Normal training in B.C.
She is in her second year with the Indian Department.
Age 21 years.
Salary $700.00 per annum and Bonus.
BUILDINGS AND PREMISES.

The building was formerly an Indian dwelling. It has been renovated and answers the purpose fairly well. It makes a fair class-room.

The windows drop from the top, making it possible to ventilate the room.

One of the Indians loaned his Organ to the school. This is quite a contribution to the school.

There are two toilets and a playground. The school has a flag.

GENERAL REMARKS.

(Under this heading the Inspector should report upon the general management of the school and offer any suggestions for improvement he may wish to make.)

Miss Coughlan does excellent work. She wins the confidence and good-will of her pupils. The tone of the school is splendid. Her teaching is scientific and systematic.

The pupils read with expression. They spell accurately. They are taught to add without counting. The tables are learned and used. The simple rules are applied to practical problems. The class-room work is very satisfactory.

Physical exercise is practised, but so far it is difficult to get them to enter into it with any degree of enthusiasm. Pupils are lined up outside and marched into school in an orderly manner. They also go out orderly.

This is another Day School that justifies its existence. I am pleased with the work. Here again the main factor in the success of the work is an interested and trained teacher. Sometimes a trained teacher fails to make good; sometimes a teacher who has not been trained makes good. There is certainly a wide difference in these two classes. I would be pleased to see our schools in the hands of trained teachers.

TEACHER'S NAME, QUALIFICATIONS, SALARY, AGE, CONDITION, SUCCESS, SUGGESTIONS, ETC.

Miss Helen Geughlan.
She has a Third Class Certificate with full Normal training.
Salary $700.00 per annum.
Age 20 years.
She is in her second year in this school.

Miss Geughlan uses her Normal methods, adapting them to local conditions. She is a real teacher.
BUILDINGS AND PREMISES.

This building is quite comfortable, and by the use of some paint and paper it is clean and attractive inside.

The windows drop from the top making it possible to secure proper ventilation.

There is a toilet with a partition dividing it.

There is ample space for a playground.

GENERAL REMARKS.

(Under this heading the Inspector should report upon the general management of the school and offer any suggestions for improvement he may wish to make.)

These pupils are making progress. They read well, pronouncing their words distinctly. They spell accurately, and write plainly.

In arithmetic they do the simple rules, adding rapidly and accurately.

Geography is taught from the maps, the pupils drawing maps for themselves. The teacher gives simple talks on the laws of health.

All manual work is well done. They do paper folding and weaving.

Singing and calisthenics are practised. One of the Indians over a year ago brought his Organ to the school so that the teacher might be the better able to teach these subjects. It is still in the class-room.

I noticed that the pupils were comfortably dressed, some of them having rubber boots on. On inquiry I found that eleven of the men of this village were working in the shipyards making good wages. There were no deaths from Influenza. This is exceptional.

Miss Helen Coughlan.

A Third Class Certificate with full normal training.

Salary $600.00 per annum.

Age 19 years. This is her first school.

Miss Coughlan is a bright girl. She is very sympathetic toward these Indian children. She is an excellent teacher. Her work is satisfactory. Her methods are modern and the pupils are making progress.
BUILDINGS AND PREMISES.

The pass room is an Indian house. It has been repaired since my last visit. The ceiling has been painted, and heavy building paper will be put on the walls at once. It has been very much improved. The windows drop from the top. There is also good light.

There is one toilet with two apartments. These are sanitary. There is lime to be used as a disinfectant. There is a good playground.

GENERAL REMARKS.

(Under this heading the Inspector should report upon the general management of the school and offer any suggestions for improvement he may wish to make.)

I visited some of the homes and talked with the parents. They are pleased with Miss Coughlan and are prepared to co-operate with her. In this way good results are attained.

The Indians have brought an Organ from one of their homes to the class room. The pupils are learning to sing. They sang two pieces. They did well. Their voices are musical and it was surprising how well they did.

Two of the pupils are in the Second Reader. They read, spell, add, and write well. They are also doing some crayon work. The general knowledge is satisfactory. These pupils have good English, due largely to the fact that the parents use English in the homes.

I hope Miss Coughlan may remain on after Christmas. She can get higher wages in a Public School. She is doing such excellent work and is so interested in the Indian children. I should like to see her remain. Perhaps an increase of $5.00 per month would decide her to remain.

(Under this heading the Inspector should report upon the general management of the school and offer any suggestions for improvement he may wish to make.)

Miss Helen Coughlan.
She has a Third-class certificate with full Normal course B.C.
Salary $700 per annum and the War Bonus of $150.
Age 21 years.
She is in her third year as teacher of this school.
BUILDINGS AND PREMISES.

It is an old building—once used a dwelling house. It has been fixed up so that it looks fairly well inside, but the teacher informs me that the wind whistles through the cracks and makes the room uncomfortable at times.

There is plenty of opportunity for the pupils to play. I took the pupils outside and gave them a lesson in Calisthenics. I also suggested to the teacher that she get outside with the pupils and teach them to play some games. I took them for a run. The pupils were delighted and entered into the spirit of the game.

There is an Organ in the class-room. It was loaned the school by one of the Indians. It has been there for nearly two years.

I was pleased to see the British flag floating in the breeze as I approached the school.

GENERAL REMARKS.

(Under this heading the Inspector should report upon the general management of the school and offer any suggestions for improvement he may wish to make.)

A little girl, Bertha Johnson, died February the 6th, 1920. She was six years of age. She had stomach trouble. This was the only death during the winter. There has been no epidemic among the pupils. Some four or five had colds at the time of my visit which accounts for the number absent.

The Department pays to some Doctors a sum of money annually. Many of these Doctors are conveniently located and should be asked to visit any schools in the territory in their jurisdiction. There should be at least one visit each year and a thorough examination of all the pupils. I most respectfully recommend this policy to the careful consideration of the Department.

I found Doctor Wilson of Alert Bay doing this work very thoroughly. His idea was that when a weakness was discovered in a pupil, to follow it up and apply the remedy.

One of the pupils read an Address in which it is declared that this Band appreciates what the Department has done in giving them a school. "We desire that you convey to the Indian Department our devotion and loyalty to the Government of CANADA."

BUILDINGS AND PREMISES.

The class-room is fairly comfortable during the mild weather. It was an Iliamna home, but some six or seven years ago (into a class-room) it was converted into a class-room. Some steps were taken during the past year to build a new building.

The teacher observes closely the heat and ventilation of the class-room.

The playground is somewhat wet at certain seasons of the year.

The school has a flag. There is plenty of good wood. One of the Indians, three years ago, brought an organ for the use of the school. It has been in the class-room ever since. This, the Inspector, is strong evidence that the Indians are gradually becoming interested in the education of their children.

GENERAL REMARKS.

(Under this heading the Inspector should report upon the general management of the school and offer any suggestions for improvement he may wish to make.)

INSPECTOR'S REPORT

KATZIE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

(New Westminster Agency.)

Date of Inspection: November 14, 1928.

Number of Pupils present:
Boys: 6 All the Boys were present.
Girls: 4 There was 1 Girl absent.

Number of Classrooms and number of desks in each: One; with 27 Single Desks.

THE TEACHER

Name: Miss Mary Winter
Age: 27

Salary: $1050.00 per annum less 10% with $25.00 per annum for janitor work less 10% for the present year.

Qualifications: B.C. Second Class Permanent Certificate. Trained Vancouver Normal School. Experience three years as substitute teacher in Vancouver, and three years in this school. Provincial Summer School Course Certificate 1925 in Rural and Indian Work.

Health: Excellent.

Success: A small bright and clean school doing "Good" work. Arithmetic is a rather weak subject but the teacher will try to raise the standard of this during the year.

Suggestions: More attention must be given to Arithmetic.

Achievement Tests: The teacher obtained these tests herself and found that the Mid Score of the Grade 5 was 71, and the Grade 4 52. These are low scores.

The teacher learned to carry out this testing while at Summer School.

Note: Since my last report, two boys of 15 years of age left school. One boy of 15 went to work, and one girl of 15 went home.

REMARKS RELATIVE TO THE EXAMINATION OF THE PUPILS

Arithmetic: Grade 1B can recognize the numbers to 10. They should start on the Combinations and Separations at once. Grade 2 have a "fair" knowledge of the Extensions or which they are working.

Grade 3 can Add and Subtract. They should be working with the Multiplication Tables. Grade 4 is working Long Division and Grade 5 is starting their work on Fractions. Grades 1, 4, & 5 have the new prescribed Texts. The work of these Grades was further tested with the All Canada Test in the Fundamentals.

Grade 2 made a Mid Score of 5, the Norm for this Grade being 7.

Grade 4 made a Mid Score of 12, the Norm for this Grade being 13.

Grade 1B made a Mid Score of 18, the Norm for this Grade being 24.

The Arithmetic may therefore be classified as "Weak".

Exercise Books: These are neat in all grades.

BUILDINGS AND PREMISES

Inspectors will please mention the number of buildings, indicate their ownership and comment on their condition.

The buildings belong to the Department. They consist of a school house and two toilets, with a small shed for coal and wood.

There is a leak in the school-house roof; this should of course be repaired. I understand that some time ago the Indian Agent had some work done on the roof, but this does not seem to have been entirely successful. I have not seen the Indian Agent for some time and he has not been made aware of any part of this report.

As recommended last year the inside plaster of the schoolroom and halls should be realkalsioned. The schoolroom is kept perfectly clean. The teacher varnished the desks since my last report.

The Boys' Toilet has been repaired since my last report.

The teacher has recommenced the inside of the windows with the help of one of the children. She bought the material herself, and in my opinion should be highly commended for her efforts to keep the school buildings in a sanitary condition.

Report on School Work Continued.

Reading: Grade 1B. The teacher taught a lesson from the Blackboard and from the Every Day Ornament Primer. This lesson was well taught. The children used markers. Their reading is too much of the "word for word" type. The class has been working through Reading Work Book for Beginners. On the whole their work is "Very Satisfactory."

Grade 2 are reading slowly from the Corona Primer 1.

Grade 3 are reading well from the Corona Reader Book 2 Part 1 Page 68.

Grade 4 are at Page 450 of Part B of the Corona Reader Book 3 and Grade 5 are at Page 51 of Part 1 of the Corona Reader Book 3.

The Reading of the school is much better than the Arithmetic.

GENERAL REMARKS

Under this heading the Inspector should report upon the general management of the school and offer any suggestions for improvement he may wish to make.

Spelling: The Grades from 2 to 5 were tested with the Morrison McCall Scale.

Grade 2 made a Mid Score of 8 which is the Norm for a Grade 1.5.

Grade 3 made a Mid Score of 20, which is the Norm for a Grade 2.

Grade 4 made a Mid Score of 27, which is the Norm for a Grade 3.1.

Grade 5 made a Mid Score of 33, which is the Norm for a Grade 5.1.

Art Work: This has been entirely ruined as far as colour is concerned by the poor paints supplied by the Department to this school. These cheap inferior paints are not permitted in most schools.

A very simple paint box is all that is required. Reeves' New Watercolour Box No. 61 is by far the best for our schools. Spectrum Refills may easily be obtained for the New Box, which originally costs retail about $4.00 per Dozen.

Control: The teacher's control of the class is "Good".

General: The teacher has small bright curtains at the sides of the windows. The schoolroom is well heated, clean, and bright, and suitable small pictures and cut-outs are displayed on the walls.

I certainly consider this a very satisfactory small school, at which satisfactory standards, with the exception of Arithmetic, are being maintained.

Very good Reading and Number Charts have been constructed by the teacher as a result of her course at Summer School. The teacher keeps a Time Table and Preview.

Writing: This is good in all grades.

Handwriting: Much better than last year's. The general design work of the children has been made less effective by the use of the very inferior paint boxes just supplied to this school. It is quite impossible to teach any colour work with such inferior material, the use of which would not be permitted by any teacher in a B.C. Provincial School.

BUILDINGS AND PREMISES

Inspectors will please mention the number of buildings, indicate their ownership and comment on their condition.

The buildings belong to the Department. They consist of a school house and two toilets, with a small shed for coal or wood.

The schoolroom is in very good condition. The inside plaster of the schoolroom and halls should be repainted this summer.

The woodwork of the interior appears to be in very good condition.

The ventilation is excellent. The lighting is very good.

The toilets were clean when I inspected them.

The door of the boys' toilet was off its hinges and resting against the wall of the toilet. A few minutes work and the use of some large screws might remedy this state of things. One of the adult Indians could very easily do this repair work, if so instructed by the Indian agent.

Report on School Work Continued.

Arithmetic: Grade 2 have finished the Combinations & separations. They have also worked through the Hexagons, and are working at addition and subtraction.

Grade 4 are about finished the work on the multiplication table in their new book, Sheffield's Practical Arithmetic.

Grades 5 & 6 are at work in the second book of the New Canadian Arithmetic by Sheffield and Sons. None of these children in Grades 4, 5, & 6 were able to give any answers to simple tests. This was very evident when the children were ranked with the All Canada Tests. In this test Grade 4 made a mid score of 10, the norm being 20. Grade 5 made a mid score of 15, the norm for the Grade being 30. Grade 6 made a mid score of 21, the norm for the Grade being 31.

GENERAL REMARKS

Under this heading the Inspector should report upon the general management of the school and offer any suggestions for improvement he may wish to make.

Singing: No singing is taught in this school.

Spelling: The Morrison School Scale was used in testing the spelling. Grade 2 made a mid score of 11, which is the norm for Grade 2. Grade 4 made a mid score of 20, which is the norm for a Grade 4. Grade 6 made a mid score of 31, which is the norm for a Grade 6. It will be seen from the above results that the spelling of the school is about normal.

Control: The teacher's control of the class was good.

General: The teacher has a small bright curtain at the side of each window. The schoolroom is well heated, clean and bright, with suitable small pictures on the walls. I consider this to be a very satisfactory little school, at which normal standards, with the exception of that in arithmetic, are being maintained. The teacher will give extra attention to the arithmetic before the next inspection.

INSPECTOR'S REPORT ON KATZIE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

Date of inspection: November 13th 1936.

Number of pupils present: 7 Boys and 4 Girls. Total 11.

Number of desks in each classroom: 23 single desks and two rear sections.

Name of teacher: Miss Mary Winter Age 30.

Health: Very Good.

Remarks relative to methods employed by teachers:

Miss Winter was trained in the Vancouver Normal School, and holds a B.C. Permanent Second Class Certificate, and in addition Provincial Summer School certificates in Rural and Indian Work 1932 & 1934 and Primary Work and Elocution 1934. Since last inspection she again attended the Provincial Summer School in Victoria taking the courses in Primary Work, and Reading and Language 1936.

Miss Winter was shown in detail what should be taken up in each Grade in Reading when I was here in October 1935, but she has permitted her anxiety for the progress of the pupils to lead her into the mistake of having so many Grades and Sub Grades that she has become confused and discouraged. She has in fact tried individual instruction which is quite hopeless in such a school as this.

There was in fact much confusion when I attempted to find out the actual Grade of each child.

I spent some time in again outlining what was to be done in each Grade and asked that the Grades should be grouped together rather than separated.

Miss Winter has a very nice manner with the children. She is much loved by them. She took notes of my suggestions and will I think attempt to do more class teaching in place of the individual work she has tried during the past year.

Her experience now extends to some nine years, the first three of which were spent as a Substitute in Vancouver City Schools and the last six in this school.

Remarks relative to the examination of pupils:

Reading: Grade 1C know some ten words BUT ONE HAS FINISHED TWO Little Indians. Grade 1B have finished Two Little Indians and the Corona Primer 1 and are at DIFFERENT places in Friday. The work done by the above Grade 1B & 1C children is "good" but they are all working at different places. Grade 2 are nearly finished Corona Primer 2. They should be reading Book 1 of the same series and will go on to this as soon as possible. They rather sing out the words, but in other respects read well. Grade 3 are quite good and read from Corona Reader Book 2. Grade 4 has finished Corona Book 2 and read Highroads Book 4 while Grade 6 has started Corona Reader Book 4 and reads Highroads Readers Book 6 as supplementary. The children all speak out well, and the reading is above the average, in many cases quite good.

The Reading Exercise Work Books are used with some success.

Geography: This has not been taught regularly lately. The teacher has got so mixed up with her many classes that she has not had time to teach this subject as suggested. She will start now however.

Singing: None done this term. This will be taken up now in preparation for a Christmas entertainment.
Arithmetic: Grade 1C are reading and writing the numbers to 9 and recognizing Groups to 8. Grade 1B are doing "Satisfactory" work in the Combinations and Separations to 6. Grade 2 can Add and Subtract with Borrowing and Carrying, BUT ARE NOT AT SAME PLACE IN THIS. Grade 3 have finished Short Multiplication and Division, know the Multiplication Tables to times 12 and are starting Long Multiplication. There work is very good indeed. Grade 4 is doing Long Multiplication and Long Division. They are a little better than average. Grade 6 works Decimals. The whole of the Arithmetic, which was greatly improved when I last inspected here, is now well above the average. Tested with the All Canada Scale:

Grade 3 made a Mid Score of 13.5, the Norm being only 7
Grade 4 made a Mid Score of 22, the Norm being 18
Grade 6 made a Mid Score of 29 which is the Norm for the Grade.

Spelling: This was tested by the Buckingham Ayres Scale. Twenty words were dictated from Columns "L" "M" and "N" for Grades 2 while Grades 2 and 3 wrote twenty words from Columns "F" "G" & "H".

Grade 2 made a Mid Score of 85%, the Norm being 84% June
Grade 3 made a Mid Score of 80%, the June 1937 Norm 94%
Grade 4 made a Mid Score of 100% the June 1937 Norm 84%

Vocational Training: The sewing done as a rule in this school has not been started yet.

The teacher tells me it will now be undertaken.

General As will be obvious from the above the Time Table is not being followed, is not perhaps in existence for I did not see one which would work. I have tried to help, but the teacher must organize the Grades and her own work herself. I have made many suggestions and outlined work. The Grades must be combined in several places. The teacher is worried as she is unable to get through the necessary work. I told her to do some Class Teaching even if some pupils have to repeat and some to go on as fast as they can. They must be brought together again. Some good Posters have been made by the teacher but these were badly displayed if displayed at all, some were under cover. The desks were badly arranged and have been so placed since my last visit. I suggested many changes. Even the teacher's desk had been moved into about the worst possible place in the room to give room for FOLK DANCES and PHYSICAL EDUCATION, which should be taken outside when the weather is good.

Attendance problem: remedies suggested, Etc.

The parents allow their children to stay up late, attend "Picture Shows" or so the teacher considers. The average attendance is small.

General Remarks:

While the schoolroom was perfectly clean it was not as neat as on former visits.

The children were not very clean. Some did not appear to have washed for some time.

The Junior Red Cross is supposed to be active here. It is obviously not active enough.

The Vocational Training has fallen off badly.

The children are still very obedient and their conduct in school is very good indeed, with one or two exceptions. In these cases I feel that the teacher is losing some of her control. One big girl was chewing gum till I told her to put it away. The teacher is to some extent losing grip on herself, and working with the large number of sub Grades which she has made herself, she feels she can hardly get through the essential work, and thus leaves out the most important things such as Vocational Training to make time for non essentials like Folk Dances.

The children are not so much backward as disorganized. Their Arithmetic and Reading are in general good, and they are fair in spelling and writing.

I believe that it will be necessary for me to pay another visit to this school in April, previous to leaving for the Prince Rupert and Nass districts.

In the mean time I should be glad if the Department would consider with care this report and compare it with previous ones on this school, the reports of the Indian Agent, etc., etc. If thought suitable perhaps a letter might be sent to Miss Winter warning her that she must organize her work better and follow a definite Time Table. She might perhaps be told that her school will again be inspected during the present school year, and that a very great change for the better is looked for, particularly in the arrangement of her room, in the reduction of the number of Sub Grades, and the actual teaching of the subjects other than Reading and arithmetic. I think some improvement might be made in the attendance if the teacher visited the Indians and insisted that the children come to school.

I should be glad to hear from the Department as to what they would wish me to do in this case.

Miss Winter is a very nice girl, with a good teaching voice and manner. The children are fond of her and she is most anxious to do all possible for the Indians. I should be very sorry indeed if the school had to be closed or if it were decided to replace her here, as I think she is a great influence for good on the Reserve.

In addition I may say that Miss Winter has always made an effort to follow my suggestions, if not in their entirety, at least to some extent. Just at the moment she appears to have lost hold on the work.

The Reverend A Gillen, O.M.I., accompanied me to the school and was present throughout my inspection. He spoke to the children, on my invitation, later. It was due to the kindness of Father Gillen that I was enabled to visit this little school. The weather was very bad and I could not have walked in from the nearest Stage stop. Father Gillen drove me in the Residential School automobile from the Indian Residential School, Mission, on the conclusion of my inspection there. He then took me on to the Devonshire Hotel, Vancouver.

You will notice that many of the items recommended in previous reports have now been authorized. The schoolroom has been reeked out, etc. I am sorry to have to report the dirty state of the schoolroom floor. I am informed that this will be put right by a thorough washing before the end of January.

The attendance at this school remains about the same from year to year. It is not large, but I believe that valuable work is being done by having a Day School on this Reserve, and I would not recommend that the school be closed.

Your obedient servant,

Gerald H. Barry,
District Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

REMARKS RELATIVE TO THE EXAMINATION OF THE PUPILS

Reading: Grade II are starting the Primer in the Highroads To Reading and are working from the Board and Flash Cards, while Grade I A have finished No Little Indians and are now at page 28 of the Highroads Primer. They have finished the two Corona Primers and some of the Corona Reader Book I. I advised that they finish the Corona Reader Book I by June. This Grade reads well and speaks out. BUILDINGS AND PREMISES

Inspectors will please mention the number of buildings, indicate their ownership and comment on their condition.

The buildings belong to the Department.
They consist of a school house, two toilets, and a small shed for coal and wood.
The inside of the school has now been reclassified. A new door has been placed on the woodshed—the school steps have been mended. There are small bright curtains at the side of the schoolroom windows. The roof of the school has been mended and covered with a coal oil and tar mixture.
A wooden picture rail has been placed in the schoolroom to which drawings and other handwork exhibits are fixed to save the plaster of the walls.
A First Aid cabinet has been placed on one of the schoolroom walls.
The display of Reading, Colour, Number, and other Charts was good.
The teacher has done everything possible to make the school attractive.
The toilets are in a perfectly clean state.

I was accompanied on my inspection by the Rev. A. Gillen, O.M.I., the Principal of the Indian Residential School Mission, and the present representative of the Oblate Order for the Catholic Missions and Catholic Indian Day Schools of the Archdiocese of Vancouver.
The Reverend Father Gillen drove me from Mission to the Katzie School. The weather was very bad and I should not have been able to get in to this little school without his help.
Father Gillen spoke to the children after my inspection. I was glad to have him with me during the inspection. He was enabled to contrast the work done at one of these little Day Schools and in the various Divisions of his own Residential School.

Christmas Tree: The children had a Christmas Tree and small concert during the Christmas season.

Schoolroom Floor: I am sorry to have to report that the floor of the school was in a very dirty condition. In my opinion this floor should be washed at the end of each two months, if not monthly.

GENERAL REMARKS

Under this heading the Inspector should report upon the general management of the school and offer any suggestions for improvement he may wish to make.

Arithmetic: Grade 1B are working at the Combinations and Separations up to Group 4 which means about to the number 8.
Grade 1A are working the Combinations and separations to about 12.
The above work is "Satisfactory". Grade 2 can Add and Subtract.
There are to start on Multiplication shortly. Grade 6 are doing 9. The above work is rather better than was the case at my last inspection. I used the All Canada Test in the Fundamentals. Grade 6 made a Mid Score of 27, the Norm being 30. This is an average result. One of the children was a little weak, but on the whole the work appears to have been taught in a satisfactory manner.

Geography: The Canadian Geography for Juniors B.C. Edition is being used as well as the Work Pads.

Singing: This is taught but there were hardly enough children present at the inspection to judge properly.

Language and Nature: The Work Books in English Usage and Composition are being used in all Grades above Grade 2. More work might be done in the Nature Work Book.

General: The teacher is giving "Satisfactory" service here.

The school is a very small one at the present time. I believe that satisfactory progress is being made by the children. Those whom I saw appeared to be making progress. The teacher's control is "Good".

Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith a copy of my proposed itinerary for the remainder of the month of September. You will remember that you asked me to let you have this in case there was need for the Indian Affairs Branch to get into touch with me while I was away from Victoria on inspection duties.

Since my arrival in Vancouver on the evening of the 14th I have been very much occupied with official duties of various kinds.

The Katzie Indian Day School was visited yesterday and help given to Miss M. Winter, the teacher. The officials in Ottawa are aware that Miss Winter does not organize her work well, and for this reason I made an inspection of her school very early in the school year. Every possible help was given to this teacher, and detailed instructions as to just what each child should attempt in the main subjects were given in order to make the work easier for Miss Winter. She seemed very pleased to have my suggestions, but it will remain to be seen how well she can carry out the detail of the work. A brief report on my visit to the Katzie Day School will be forwarded to you to-morrow.

Miss Weaver our senior teacher at the Skidegate Indian Day School appears to have resigned her position without any warning, on being appointed to a teaching position under the Provincial Department of Education in a school near Vancouver. Under the new arrangement the schools in the Queen Charlotte Islands do not open till October 1st, but the boat leaves Vancouver to-day.

Dr. Osterhout the Superintendent of the United Church was away on vacation as he believed the whole of the arrangements with regard to the next term had been made. In his absence I gave what help I could to Miss Money Dr. Osterhout's Secretary, and after meeting an experienced United Church teacher who was a candidate for the position at Skidegate, the necessary telegram and letter was sent to the United Church officials in Toronto, who were in touch with the Indian Affairs Branch in Ottawa.

A very experienced teacher, Mrs Moses, was nominated to the Indian Affairs Branch by the United Church, and from what I saw of this lady I believe she will be a great success at Skidegate. There was not sufficient time to cover all the ground but I did what I could to indicate to Mrs Moses the more pressing needs of the classroom she will take over at Skidegate.

I should be glad if you would forward this letter and a copy of my itinerary to Ottawa, with any covering remarks you may care to make.

Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on the Katzie Indian Day School, New Westminster Agency, which I inspected yesterday, March 15th.

The attached report should be read in conjunction with one made after an inspection on November 19th 1936, a copy of which is on file in Victoria.

The present inspection was carried out in compliance with instructions contained in a letter from the Indian Affairs Branch following the receipt in Ottawa of my former report.

I am certainly glad to say that a definite effort has been made by Miss Winter to carry out the instructions of the Indian Affairs Branch, whether given to her in a letter from the Chief of the Training Division or by myself during inspections. On the whole there has been a distinct improvement in the organization of the school since my last visit.

I have asked Miss Winter to develop the Vocational Training at present given at this school. She is considering just what can be done in the way of Arts and Crafts next year, and will probably take a course in either Manual Arts or Arts and Crafts if she can find a suitable one this summer.

A new Union Jack is being requisitioned. The old flag is so badly torn and worn out that I think the provision of a new one is badly needed.

I do not consider that it is necessary to make a change of teachers here at the present time. This should not be considered to mean that I am satisfied with the progress of the children. I do think that Miss Winter is of some use here apart from her ability as a teacher. Her influence is all for the good of the Indians and their children. A more effective teacher would get the pupils further on in their academic studies, but might not be of as great a help to them in other ways. If Miss Winter can develop the Arts and Crafts during the school year 1937-38 I shall be satisfied.

Yours sincerely,

Gerald H. Barry
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
INSPECTOR'S REPORT ON KATZIE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL
Roman Catholic Church New Westminster Agency.

Date of inspection: March 15, 1937.
Number of pupils present: 7 Boys and 3 Girls; Total 10.
Number of classrooms: One.
Number of desks in each classroom: 23 Single Desks with 4 Rear Sections in addition

Name of teacher: Miss Mary Winter. Age 30.

Health: The teacher's health has been good since my last inspection with the exception that she was away from school for three days during this period with influenza.

Remarks relative to methods employed by teacher:

Miss Winter is very much interested in all that is for the good of the children and their parents. She was trained in the Vancouver Normal School, and holds a B.C. Second Class Certificate. She has attended the Provincial Summer Schools in Victoria on a number of occasions. She holds Summer School qualifications in Indian & Rural Work 1932 & 1934, Primary Work and Elocution 1934, and Primary 1936. For some three years she was a Substitute Teacher in the Vancouver City Schools. She has been here for some six years.

While Miss Winter has a very good manner with the children, and is much loved by them, she is not a very great success as a teacher. She becomes very easily confused and has to be told quite clearly what promotions it is best to make and what should be taught in each Grade. She has had hours of instruction from me in the Provincial Summer Schools and during inspections, but she is not able to make use of one tenth of what she has been told.

During my previous visit to this school, when things were found in a very confused state, Miss Winter was given very definite instructions as to what was to be taught in each Sub Grade of Grade 1 and Grade 2. The result has not come up to my expectations; but I can say that the Reading in the various Grades has improved.

The Arithmetic is very weak at the present time, and particularly poor in Grades 1C and 1B.

Remarks relative to the examination of pupils:

Reading: This has improved since last October. Grade 1C know some 50 words. They are reading and should finish Two Little Indians by the end of June. They will be ready to start Friends and Corona Primer 1 in September. Their reading is still "word for word" but they speak out fairly well. Grade 1B have finished Two Little Indians and Corona Primer 1. The girl in this Sub Grade is at Page 31 of Corona Primer 2, but the boy is not as far on. The girl is ready for Grade 2B in September. Grade 2B have now finished Corona Primer 2 and are at Page 32 of Corona Reader Book 1. The work of this Grade is on the whole quite satisfactory. The reading is rather "word for word" but one child will be ready for Grade 3B in September while one must remain in Grade 2B. Grade 4B and 4A are working at Corona Book 2 in different places and are reading Highroads Readers Books 4 and 3. Reading is good and the children speak up. Grade 6 pupil was not present but is I am informed reading Corona Reader Book 4 and Highroads Book 6.
Report on Katzie Indian Day School:

Arithmetic: Grade 1C can read and write the numbers to 9 and can recognize Groups to 9. They should start the Combinations and Separations now. Grade 1B are supposed to know the Combinations and Separations to 6 on the statement of the teacher. As a matter of fact they do know these from Flash Cards but have no idea of doing the same work from the Blackboard. I have explained all this to the teacher and asked that the Board be used. Grade 2B can add and subtract without borrowing or carrying. They are starting the harder work now, and I taught a short lesson in Subtraction with borrowing to correct a wrong method being used by the teacher. These children must use the DECOMPOSITION METHOD at present. Grade 4B is working Short Multiplication and Division and are starting Long Multiplication and Long Division. Grade 4A has finished Long Division but will have to review this, to be ready for Grade 5B in September. Grade 6 was absent but is said to be working Decimals. She should go on to Per Cent.

Tested with the All Canada Test in the Fundamentals:
Grade 4A made a Mid Score of 17, the Norm being 20
Grade 4B made a Mid Score of 18, the Norm being in this case 18.

Writing: This is particularly weak throughout the school.
Grades 4 and 6 use the Maclean Manuals, but the Juniors have been writing from copies on the Board placed there by the teacher. I have suggested that these Juniors use the Bailey Manuals now at the school, as they must have some sort of Manual. Grade 1B must write in their exercise books also. Grade 1C should do so also, but at present are only writing on the Boards. From Grade 3 up ink is used. It might be used in Grade 2.

Spelling: This is good as is usual in these schools where insufficient time is given to the completion of the various Work Books, Geography, Nature, Etc.

In the Buckingham Ayres Scale in Spelling:
Grade 4A made a Mid Score of 85% and Grade 4B a Mid Score of 80% the June Norm being in each case about 88%.

Geography: An attempt is being made to teach this with the help of The Book of Boys and Girls Round the World and Journeys Near and Far. Not sufficient work has been done but a Project on Japan was on display. I have asked the teacher to give more attention to Geography.

Elementary Science: The text supplied by the Branch, Happy Hours in Garden Field and Woodland is being used. I have suggested that Book 1 of the Pathways in Science be used by the teacher in the Primary Grades and the suggested practical work done this Spring.

Singing: The children sang quite well for me, but the teacher is not giving enough time to this. I asked that a few minutes daily be given to singing.

Language: I doubt that sufficient work is being done in the various Work Books.

General Achievement: The children are backward in Arithmetic particularly in the Primary Grades. Grades 4B and 4A wrote the B.C. Achievement Test for Juniors 1934 for me and the following low scores were made:
Grade 4A made a Mid Score of 23, the Norm being about 27
Grade 4B pupils made scores of 14, and 1, the Norm being 25.

While the standing of the pupils is very much below the average of the Indian Day Schools in B.C. the work has been better organized since my last inspection and the Reading much improved.

She purchased out of her own funds the complete Vancouver course while attending Summer School this year. This course cost her $4.85 and I much doubt that it was worth it as it is arranged for "white" pupils who could never produce the work these Indians can if they are given the chance.

Dear Mr. Launt:

I have received your letter of the 16th inst., which quoted, at the Department's request, the information they wished me to receive.

The Inspector has evidently given me another bad report.

I protest that this report is not fair, as it was given on Oct. 6th, only twelve school days after the opening of the term. That does not give any teacher who has twenty children to day, and six grades to teach much chance of getting organized. The children had also been out of school three months, owing to my long illness, during practically the whole month of June. Also the Inspector has never told me at any time that he was going
To give me a bad report. He only gave two or three criticisms, and as he has always done so, even in days when he was apparently satisfied with my work, I took them to be only in the nature of recommendations for improvement.

I wish to protest also against private reports, which the teacher does not see. This is never done in the B.C. provincial schools. Copies of the teacher's report are rendered in triplicate, and the teacher always receives one copy, whether it is excellent, satisfactory or bad. In applying for a new school, we can furnish copies of the Inspector's reports which we are bound to do in that case. Without these it is practically impossible for an experienced teacher to secure a new position anywhere else.

I have always endeavored, and will still continue to render satisfactory service to the Department, and I appreciate the help and consideration you have always given me in my work.

Yours sincerely,

Mary Hunter.

Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on the Katzie Indian Day School, Roman Catholic Church, New Westminster Agency, which I inspected yesterday, December 6th.

I feel that the Department would wish me to make a very detailed report on the conditions existing at the above school in view of the fact that I consider them highly unsatisfactory, particularly from an administrative point of view.

The teacher, Miss Daly, was placed here on first appointment to take the place of Miss Winter, moved after about ten years to the Seton Lake School. Miss Daly is the only daughter of Mr. C.O. Daly, the teacher of the Skwah Indian Day School, on whom I reported a few days ago.

It was somewhat difficult to carry out my inspection as Miss Daly's attitude was almost hostile. She went so far as to interrupt me in my work by suggesting what the children did. I did not know how much I could expect from them, and the difficult conditions under which the work of the school was carried out. She managed to so twist around the suggestions made to her in my own office that they carried quite different meanings from those I had intended in trying to assist her when she was first appointed. Others, had they been present, would no doubt have considered her attitude to me and to my advice and suggestions highly impertinent from such a young inexperienced teacher to one now nearing the end of his professional life.

In a conference with Mr. Indian Agent Daunt in New Westminster after this inspection I explained the attitude of the teacher to the officials of the Department, including his own stenographer, Dominion Constable Higginbottom, and myself, and I suggested that were he to receive the same sort of impudence he might do well to take a very strong stand and report the matter at once to the Department. Such an action as the temporary suspension of the teacher to learn the Department's wishes would not under these conditions be perhaps a wrong course to follow.

The teacher complained of a number of things, the main headings being:

1. The school was too dark, due mainly to the fact that there is a wooded piece of land some distance in front of the windows. She wanted the Indians or others to cut down the trees, and clear the bush, but said that after a number of letters to the Indian Agent she could not get action in this matter.
Miss Daly also wanted electric lighting in her school the electric light wires passing quite close to the school.

I replied that it was the first time that I had ever heard of a teacher asking for trees etc., to be cut down on another person's land to improve the conditions in the school, that I much doubted that such action would in any case be possible as the Indians would at best have to be paid for the work even if approved, and that as far as the electric light question was concerned the Department had made a decision not to have it in the school, and the matter was thus closed.

2. Miss Daly stated that she could not get the school warm enough for the children on cold days, as the heating stove was too small and in poor repair.

When I explained that Dominion Constable Higginbottom in thirty minutes had raised the temperature in the room to around 70 degrees by increasing the fuel on the fire, Miss Daly told me that this was a foolish reply, as the day was a warm one when Constable Higginbottom was there to inquire into this matter.

Miss Daly then, the heater not having had coal on for the preceding one and a half hours, said she felt the room cold and took out a little thermometer to test the temperature. After a further half hour I found the temperature sixty degrees with windows open and at the end of the morning's work.

I examined the heater, which is of the circulating type and burns coal or at times wood. It has had I understand some ten years use here, and due to big fires needs some repair to the top, where air can get in and thus reduce the draft.

In my opinion whether the stove is repaired or not, and considering the mild climate of the coast, it is quite possible to heat the room in a satisfactory manner, provided the fuel is added properly. I have no intention of recommending a new heater for this school and informed the Indian Agent.

The teacher tells me that the fire is lighted at 7.30 a.m. on cold mornings, by Duncan Moody, and that Mrs. Moody does the janitor work for $2.50 per month. Miss Daly did not hesitate to say that such sum was inadequate.

3. Miss Daly complains that she gets her shoes wet and stockings torn by undergrowth and briars around the school. In reply I suggested she should wear gum boots.

4. Miss Daly states that there are two small leaks in the schoolroom roof. This has nothing to do with me but I did mention the matter to Mr. Indian Agent Daunt. Probably quite minor repairs are all that would be necessary.

5. Miss Daly did not hesitate to say that the reduction of the academic year to one of nine months had kept the children back in their work. How she could have come to such a decision without any experience I do not know. I pointed out that in the schools so far inspected this year, I could not detect any such retardation.

While there were other complaints, I think the above will indicate the teacher's attitude.
The teacher was absent on November 8th 1940 when she attended a teachers' convention at Chilliwack, near where her parents live. The Katzie Indian Day School was closed that day without permission from anyone. This matter has been reported by the Indian Agent I understand.

Miss Daly when asked why she closed the school without permission informed me that she thought I liked teachers to attend conventions. I told Miss Daly that none of us in B.C. had the power to give permission for the school to be closed and that such a matter would have had to be dealt with by the Department at Ottawa. In any case Miss Daly only wrote to the Indian Agent of her intention to close the school the evening before and in no case could Mr Daunt have received the letter in time.

General Remarks

I do not see how the retention of a teacher in an Indian school, when such teacher is highly critical of the actions of the Department or its officials, could be justified.

There is the danger that such teacher would, perhaps without intending it, say things in school which would cause the Indians to become disturbed.

At present the Union Jack is not being flown here though one has been provided. The teacher's explanation is that the wires on the flag pole have become tangled, and that she is unable to fix them.
Miss Daly informed me that she hopes later to obtain a position in a Provincial school. She was anxious when I left the school that she would be given a good report. She asked if she would receive a copy of my report, and was informed that teachers in Indian schools did not receive copies of my reports on the schools.

I recommended Miss Daly to modify her highly critical attitude to the Department and its officials.

The authorized length of the academic year at this school is one of nine months, from October 1st to June 30th yearly.

Miss Daly is being allowed salary at the rate of $90.00 per teaching month, less the usual deductions.

The operating expense at this school is increased through the necessity for a boat from Barnston Island to transport those children living there to and from school.

When costs for fuel, janitor services, etc., are taken into consideration, it is somewhat doubtful if the Department is justified in keeping this small school open for a nine month academic year, particularly in war time, when there is need for strict economy.

Recommendation:

I am not satisfied with the attitude of the teacher, but have not sufficient grounds at present to request the Department to terminate her appointment.

As there are two non-Indian children attending the school, the real average attendance of the Indian children may perhaps in round numbers be taken as 8 in October and 7 in November of this year. With a present total of 10 strictly Indian children I do not expect the average attendance to exceed 8 which would be a higher percentage attendance than in many Indian day schools.

Under the above circumstances I consider that the Department might well close the school at least during the present war period. A few of the children might possibly be taken into St. Mary's Residential School, and as the older ones completed their period in school the younger might be admitted there, where in any case the education is of a far more worth while nature that at Katzie.

Should the Department for some reason not agree with me that the Katzie school be closed, I would recommend that the academic year be reduced to one of only five months, as has been done in the case of at least two Anglican day schools, Kingcome Inlet and Mamalilikulla. This would turn the Katzie Indian day school into a seasonal school, operating during the winter months, say from October 1st to February 28th or from November 1st to March 31st yearly.

As this school was opened this year on October 1st it should in my opinion be closed at the end of February if the Department accept the seasonal school plan in preference to the more general plan of closing the school for the period of the war.

In either case I would advise that the teacher be notified, as soon as the Department has come to a decision in the matter, that her services may not be needed after the end of February. This would allow her to seek a position in the Provincial schools for the term opening after the Christmas vacation. She in such case would no doubt be informed that the attendance did not justify more than a seasonal school at Katzie.
In conclusion I may say that I have no objection to a copy of this confidential letter being sent to Mr. Indian Agent A.O.N. Daunt for his information, on the understanding that the contents are in fact of a confidential nature.

It may be that you would like to have a report from Mr. Daunt himself regarding the suggestion for either the closing of the Katzic school or the reduction of the academic year to one of five months.

I regret that it has been necessary to make such a lengthy report on this school, but it is better that the Department should have as many as possible of the facts on which to base a decision.

Yours very truly,

Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on the Katzie Indian Day School, Roman Catholic Church, New Westminster Agency, which I inspected this morning.

The general conditions were much better than have been noted on former inspections.

The provision of a ferry launch to bring children to school from the opposite side of the Fraser River has resulted in a definite increase in the average attendance. There is no Provincial school where these children could possibly receive an education, and there is no room for them in any Residential School.

The school is clean, furniture etc., now well arranged. I am glad the Department saw fit to supply some very elementary Manual Training equipment and sewing materials. I hope that the work now being done will be continued, for it has been very successful during the past year. The teacher has carried out the suggestions made to her at previous inspections.

Book shelves, little tables, book ends, etc., have been made by the boys and later decorated with Indian designs from the sheets I sent to the school. The girls have made use of Indian design in a number of ways, and also learned plain sewing.

One boy in Grade IA not shown in the averages as enrolled or present is ROBERT CHARLIE. I am informed by the teacher that his mother is an Indian and is now blind and living with her own parents on the Indian Reserve, while the father, who is white, works at or near Deroche. This young boy lives with his mother on the Indian Reserve and attends this school, there being no other for him to attend.

The progress of the children has been better since my last visit. The teacher is carrying out the various instructions given to her to the best of her ability. Her manner with the little children is particularly good, and her attitude to her work is "Excellent".

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

She is not able to make use of much of what she has been taught, as she would appear to suffer from a very confused state of mind. Were it not that she has done some very nice work in Handwork and is teaching the children to sew embroidery and make aprons etc., and instructing the boys in elementary work with the set of tools at this school, I should recommend that she be replaced.
