General Remarks:

I should like to see a still greater effort put into the Arts and Crafts work. The teacher is able to make a success of this sort of instruction.

The boys could cut toys out of three ply wood if they had a large fret saw and sufficient blades. They have made some nice book ends which they are decorating with Indian designs.

There are some tools at this school. A new large cupboard should be constructed for the tools and other material for the Manual Training.

I should like to recommend the grant of not more than ten dollars to provide a few more tools, particularly the necessary small fret saw outfit and sufficient lumber for the construction of a large cupboard for the tools.

Another small table is required for the DRESSING CORNER. These things can be made by the boys if they have the lumber. Display boards for the children's work for exhibition purposes will also be needed and can be made at the school.

Possibly a pair of hand carders could be purchased out of the above suggested sum of $10.00 so that the children could go ahead with the carding of local wool which could then be spun and knit by the girls.

It is only along such lines as this that we can hope for much success at this school under the present teacher.

I have sent a sheet of Indian designs to the school. These only cost 10¢ for a large coloured sheet and I have provided them for a number of schools. Other schools have been supplied when the teachers sent a dime to the Vancouver office for such material.

With reference to Departmental letter 153-18-5 of November 13th 1938 I have made a recommendation that the school be lighted with electric light.

This matter was gone into in detail in my letter of December 2nd addressed to the Indian Commissioner. Four 150 watt lights would be sufficient for the schoolroom which is not a very large room. Four 200 watt lights are used in the Provincial schoolrooms when electric light is available, 600 watts being the maximum for one circuit. There would in this school be need for two 60 watt lights one in the hall and one on the porch as well as the four in the schoolroom. The total would therefore come to 720 watts if my recommendation is followed.

The monthly minimum charge would be $1.00 the Indian Agent informs me, and the capital expenditure about $125.00 I consider that if we are to continue to operate this school the above expenditure is justified, but it should be noted that every available child must attend to keep us a reasonable average.

Dear Sir:

I beg to forward herewith report by Capt. G.H. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools for B.C., together with his covering letter of the 7th ultimo, with respect to his inspection on the 6th of December, 1940, of the Katzie Indian Day School, New Westminster Agency, B.C.

It will be observed from this report that Inspector Barry is not satisfied with the attitude of the teacher. Miss Daly, of course, is a young inexperienced teacher, which probably accounts to some extent for her general attitude towards Inspector Barry during his inspection of her school.

The Indians of Katzie are among the very few in the Province who remain in residence on their Reserve throughout the year, the reason being that the men are Fraser River fishermen and are employed all the year round on the River in close proximity to the village. For this reason I consider the school should continue on the present basis so long as the average attendance is satisfactory. Should sufficient children be available to keep the school in operation for the full school year, I feel it would be a mistake to reduce the term to one or five months. Perhaps I should add that Mr. Indian Agent Daunt is also of this opinion.

I would recommend that the school be again inspected in May or June, following which a definite decision could be reached as to its immediate future.

Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on the Katzie Indian Day School, Roman Catholic Church, New Westminster Agency, which I inspected yesterday, April 23rd.

This particular inspection was carried out in accordance with Departmental instructions, and in forwarding my present report I would refer you to my confidential letter of December 7th last and the report on the Katzie school following my visit ther on December 6th 1940.

You will be glad to know that conditions at the Katzie school are now very much improved. The attendance has in particular been increased. Two of the sixteen children enrolled are Chester and Audie Miller, non Indians I believe, whose cases were dealt with in my letter of December 7th 1940.

Miss Daly has greatly improved in her general attitude, and has followed my suggestions given to her during my inspection of December last. This teacher had no idea that I should visit her school at this particular time, yet the Union Jack was flying, the school perfectly clean and work being carried on properly.

While the academic work is in general much better the Arithmetic in Grades 4 and 5 is still very weak. On the other hand the Arithmetic in Grade 2 is excellent. Tested with the All Canada Test in Fundamentals:

- Grade 2 made a score of 11 Norm for Grade 3 13
- Grade 4 made a score of 3 Norm being 21
- Grade 5 made a score of 18 Norm being 27

The pupil tested in Grade 4 is "null".

Reading is very good in Primary Grades and satisfactory to good in Grades 4 and 5.

I suggested that the Geography of B.C. be taught to the older pupils, and at the request of the teacher I outlined a suitable method for her and the children.

The children were much more responsive to my teaching on this occasion. They were in general clean and the teacher's control was very good. She has modified the attitude complained of in my last report, and should in my opinion be allowed to continue in charge of this school. Miss Daly has informed me that she may seek an appointment in a Provincial school when she meets the Provincial Inspectors at Summer School. I asked her to let the Department have at least a month's notice should she wish to resign her present position.

While the grades given to Miss Daly in the attached report may seem very low I would ask that the general improvement from those of the last report be noted. Miss Daly states her medical adviser some few months ago stated that she was on the verge of a nervous breakdown at that time. She is now much better and able to carry on her work at the school. No school days appear to have been lost through the above noted condition.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Ottawa, April 8th, 1910.

Sir,

During last summer the Department had correspondence through the Victoria Office with the late Agent, Mr. Lorenz, in reference to the establishment of a saw-mill on the Kincolith Reserve. Finally the Department agreed to stand pledged for machinery to equip a mill to the extent of $1250.00, as soon as the moiety of the cost to be furnished by the Indians was in some way forthcoming. A condition attached to this grant was that the first lumber cut was to be used in the erection of a school-house at no cost to the Department.

The Department was of opinion that a grant for the mill, which would be a permanent and valuable asset, was preferable to an appropriation for the erection of a school building, which was under consideration.

A new school-house is much needed and the Department is prepared to carry out its part of the agreement. If the Indians are prepared to stand by their original proposal the erection of a school building will have to be undertaken by the Department, but it is thought that, in view of the benefit that would accrue to the Indians from a mill with which they could supply lumber for the erection of houses and for municipal improvements, the carrying out of the above-mentioned proposition would be much to their advantage.

Dear Sir,

I am pleased to say that I have been now laboring among the Indians of your district for the past 35 years. It was my privilege to help amongst the Indians and succeeded in converting many of them. From June 6th to October 1st, I was the first to establish a mission amongst the Indians of Queen Charlotte's Islands in 1876 when they were still quite uncivilized.

And I founded the Upper Skeena Mission in 1881 at Hazelton. I have been here working amongst the Skeena Indians for over 20 years and it is in their behalf I now write.

We have never received any help from the government towards a school building but though in 1873 we were overtaken by a great fire which swept away all our mission buildings including a new church just completed and 30 Indian houses.

I appealed to the Indian Department for help but we did not receive a cent. I erected a small school room out of my own personal means and then appealed to some friends in England who assisted me to help the Indians who had lost all and eventually we succeeded in rebuilding our church. This school room is now much too small and injurious to the children's health. We were informed three years since that a grant of $1000 would be made towards a new school building. Sadly, we sent in a petition to the Department hoping that this promised grant of $1000 might be made toward...
Small Saw Mill instead, to which Indians in public meetings as before proposed to add $20 each which would amount to a total of $1100. Now with the promised $1000 from the Indian Department would be sufficient to purchase a Mill. On these conditions our Indians engage to erect a School building themselves from the first lumber drawn which building will be subject to examination and approval by the Indian Agent for this District. By the Saw Mill they would be enabled to keep up their roads, fences &c. also in good repair as also to help them in house building.

We have lately received a reply from the Department to this effect:

The Department will pay a grant of $1000 to the Indian Council when the School house has been erected and approved by Indian Agent.

It is this I would beg you to have charged as you will see that no advantage is gained as under those circumstances the Indians must find or raise the same total for the erection of the Mill. As I know the Saw Mill will cost $2500 I would respectfully beg that the Indian Department advance half this amount towards the School house building the Indians to engage to complete said building from first lumber drawn in a satisfactory manner.

We shall greatly appreciate any help you can render us towards this end and with kind regards

I remain dear Sir,

Yours very faithfully,

W.H. Collison, (Creeheadman)

Sir,

In reply to your letter No. 119496/1, dated the 7th ultimo, in which you request that I take up with the Right Reverend the Lord Bishop of Caledonia the matter of appointing a fully qualified teacher for the Indian Day school, I would suggest that the Department, through Mr. Inspector Tyson, more thoroughly investigate the situation at Kincolith, in support of my reason for so doing. I beg to make the following observations for the information of the Department.

Prior to the year 1904 the missions on the Nass River were largely under the supervision of the Methodist Church, but on account of that Church being unable to supply the missions with teachers and missionaries, the people sent a petition to the then Indian Agent and the then Bishop of Caledonia, asking that the Anglican Church take over the stations on the Nass River of the latter, and of the former that a denominational Bylaw which they thought existed be changed from the Methodist to the Anglican Church. The responsible authorities of the two Churches then mutually agreed to the change, and buildings which belonged to the Methodist Church at Lekhalap were transferred to the Anglican Church for the sum of fifteen hundred dollars. Since that time the Anglican Church has endeavoured to keep the missions supplied with suitable missionaries and teachers, and the Methodist Church has created missions in other parts of the coast, leaving the Nass River missions to themselves. Nevertheless for some
reason or other the missionaries of the Methodist Church have appeared aggrieved at the method of the Anglican Church adopted for the requirements of the Hans missions, and it would appear that whenever the Indians have expressed a desire to return again to the care of the Methodist Church their attitude has not been discourteous, as might be expected in view of the mutual arrangement referred to.

I have just returned from the Hans river, where I took the census, and while there was asked one night to attend a meeting of the people at Lek-halzep. When I got there the Indians expressed themselves very strongly in favor of a change from the Anglican to the Methodist Church. This was their main subject.

I would, moreover, state that to reach the end in view these Indians have recently intimidated the resident missionary of the Church of England, who, desiring to return from the colchuck fisheries at Fishery Bay where he had been with his people, was told that if he returned to Lek-halzep he might be killed, and that they wanted the mission house for a Methodist missionary. They did not want the Anglican Church any more. At that time it was necessary for me to protect the missionary referred to—the Rev. Sylvester Bone, M.B., and I wrote a letter to the Chief Constable, making him aware of the consequences of intimidating the missionaries, also advising him that if the majority of the people were disposed of coming under the supervision of the Methodist Church so that his people did go in a civil and Christian-like manner, by taking their case to the Bishop, in which case I would do anything in my power to stand by the Indians' interests.

In view of these facts the Department will readily see the advisability dealing cautiously with this matter.

I am also of the opinion that those Indians reported to have asked an Inspector over for a
new teacher have no children of their own, and have never evinced an interest either in the school or in the missionaries, resident at Kincolith.

Another important matter for the Department's consideration is, that the Venerable Archdeacon's is the only white people's home in Kincolith. It is not at all likely that if Miss Collison is deprived of the position as teacher the home of the Archdeacon will be open for the accommodation of her successor, in which case it would be necessary for the Department to erect a house for another teacher on the reserve, besides having to pay a much larger salary for a more competent teacher.

While Miss Collison is young I have never doubted her efficiency as a teacher. In fact she has had a good education herself, and is thoroughly conversant with the languages of the Indians. The fact that while the Zak-Kalazap mission was furnished with no less than fourteen different teachers and missionaries, in most instances at the request of the people, should convince the Department these Indians of the near villages will ask for a new teacher whether that teacher is efficient or not, and are glad when they are able to give missionaries subsequently appointed with the fact that "we shifted Mr. So-and-so and we can shift you too if we like". Thus catering to the whimsical spasms of the Indians has a tendency to lessen the influence of the teachers, and their lot is not by any means pleasant.

His Lordship the Bishop has recently asked the missionaries to interchange their respective fields. The programme is that the Venerable Archdeacon Collison remove to Letiakatla, the Rev. J. R. de Cullagh, of Aiyansh, to Kincolith, the Rev. Mr Price, of Citwanger, to Aiyansh and appoint a new man for Citwanger. I would, therefore, recommend that the Department defer its decision in the matter of a successor to Miss Collison until the way appears more favourable for a change. If, however, the Dep-
artment still wishes me to take the matter up with Bishop Du Vernet I will do so on receipt of your instructions.

I have the honor to beg,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Pedley,

In reference to a letter from Venerable Archdeacon Collison regarding the salary paid at the Kincolith School, as stated in this letter, the salary is $400.00 per annum. Mr. Collison makes reference to Massett where a salary of $900.00 is paid, but you will see from the attached schedule, showing the schools and salaries, that this and Metlakatla are the only schools in British Columbia where $75.00 a month is paid and it should be remembered that the teacher at Massett has to change his location when the Indians go to the canneries. This entails considerable trouble and expense. The enrolment also at each of these two schools is more than double that at Kincolith and during the past year the Kincolith School was only open 148 days owing to the absence of the Indians. Late reports on Miss Collison's work are very favourable, but in 1911 Mr. Green, the Inspector, recommended that an experienced teacher, properly qualified, be secured for this village. I do not think that the attendance and length of time the school was kept open would justify
justify the Department in paying the salary asked by the Archdeacon, but an increase to $500.00 might be allowed. In view of the fact that the teacher is a daughter of the Archdeacon I cannot see how he makes any claim to have borne part of the burden of the salary himself.

A.F. MacKenzie

Sir,

I have the honour to submit herewith my report and Diary for the month of January, together with receipts for expenditure in connection with travelling for that month.

On Friday, January 9th, I visited the Kincolith Indian Day School which is taught by Miss Collison. I found the school well kept and the pupils clean and tidy. Whilst the attendance might be better, the real difficulty in connection with the problem of school attendance, not only at Kincolith, but also other Indian Day schools in the Agency, is largely caused by the fact that as the Coast opens up and various industries are established, offering work to the Indians, the parents remain away from the villages for longer periods than formerly with the result that the education of the children is neglected just at an age when they should be at school. To my mind the best way of meeting these new conditions is by sending as many children as possible to Indian boarding schools which are under the complete control and supervision of the Government. When the Royal Commission visited the Nass River in 1915 I believe the establishment of a boarding and industrial school for the Nass was recommended.

Mr. Scott,

Miss Alice M. Collison, teacher of the Kincolith Indian Day School, applies for an increase in her salary. She states that the salary she receives now is barely sufficient to pay for her board.

She is no doubt earnest and faithful in her duties and I would judge from the reports received that she is doing as good work as some of the other teachers who are qualified and receive a higher salary. Sir,

I have the honor to transmit my report for the months of October and November.

Kincolith:

Arriving at Kincolith on Saturday evening, October 13th, I remained there until the arrival of the weekly steamer on the following Monday. Sir:

I have the honour to forward my Monthly Report for June 1931.

Replying to the letter addressed to me by the Indian Commissioner for B.C. dated June 22nd, 1931, file number 11/21632 in regard to the third paragraph of my report for May 1931, which deals with school attendance at Kincolith, I would state that this matter is one of great difficulty and was the subject of a report by me dated March 11th, 1930, Indian Agent's file S-E-1446. This report was not replied to and no authority was given in connection with a suggestion made in the last paragraph of the said report, consequently I am quite powerless to adequately deal with the matter.

The matter of rounding up children, playing truant on their own volition for which the parents are in no way to blame, is a simple one and has no connection with the difficulty referred to which is entirely to do with the neglect and indifference on many of the parents and guardians. Some complication was caused by the present teacher at Kincolith reporting for the month of April 1931, that the attendance was satisfactory, while I had reported that it was not. This difference of opinion was probably due to the fact, that the lady was inside the school, marking pupils present, whenever they arrived—sometime during the day while I was on the outside resorting to many different methods in order to get them there.

In regard to cases of absence where the children are not found on the streets during school hours or not readily located, although not absent from the village, I have to depend to some extent on information supplied by the teacher and owing to the fact that the lady is compelled to reside in my house, I have heard more of this than, probably, I would have done otherwise. From October 1930 to March 1931, the lady took every opportunity of complaining of the poor attendance and other matters to me, but evidently not to the Indian Agent. I have advised the lady, that her best policy is to officially report on matters affecting her duties, accurately and that I have gone to the limit of my powers in order to assist her. The Kincolith Day school has now been closed two weeks and it would of course, be premature to state whether this problem will arise next session, or not.

E. G. Newnham.
Dominion Constable.

Dear Mr. Holy,

Thank you for your letter. I gathered from it that you are a link between officialdom and the scattered teachers on the reserve. It is nearly eleven years since I began teaching Indian children so perhaps if I still have a few of my ideas on the subject you may find a grain or two of wisdom in this letter which is not written as a report or criticism but as one worker to another in the same field.

To begin with I entirely agree with your idea that
more time ought to be devoted to manual occupations. I feel convinced that vocational, practical training is more important to our Indians (and to most white children too) than purely academic work. Of course I believe everyone ought to be able to read and perhaps write a simple letter (or order to Eaton's), but I mean beyond that.

Acting on this idea I have spent one afternoon a week teaching the girls sewing and kindred arts. We have a sewing machine and several pupils have turned out wearable garments. No child is allowed to use the machine until her hand sewing passes muster. Some artistic and colorful embroideries have been done too and some knitting.

As there seemed no official means of obtaining materials I used some petty money to buy the first lot.
then we had a sale and bought more material which has been made up ready for another sale next week.

For some reason there are not many school age boys in this village so I just taught them such things as sewing on buttons and simple basketry. There are quite a number of little boys who will soon be going to school and some provisions will have to be made for them.

About the follow-up system I have no comprehensive plans. Many of the young married couples here are pupils I once taught, now at Alert Bay Residential School and very friendly relations exist between them and me.

Now for a couple of suggestions for this particular school. I do hope there will soon be a playground for the children. The school lot
is 200 feet long but it is covered all over by trees, bushes, and dead brush. The children and I did as much towards cleaning it up as our strength would allow but it was a hopeless task.

A board walk runs through the grounds to a little platform in front of the door. This walk, in places three feet or more from the ground, is all the school playground for my 52 pupils unless they cross the creek or go off in front of the church. The "lardy" problem is ever present. If the grounds were cleared we could have a flagpole and a flag.

As my classroom is used for Sunday School, a small organ has been lent to us. I suggest that every school needs one.

Then there is the problem of the school wood. Could not this item be included in the
yearly estimate and same provision made for it? It is hard to ask a man to wait months for his pay and often most inconvenient for the teacher to advance the money and wait months for a refund.

Taken all round though, this is not a bad little school. I feared much worse in my last white school. In many ways I shall be sorry to leave it but I hope to go to one near Merritt, B.C. (in Mr. Barber's agency) next September.

I hope this letter is not too long and that it is what you wanted me to do.

Yours faithfully,

(Miss) Edith M. Sylvain.

Dear Sir:

In reviewing Inspector Barry's diary for the month of December which was forwarded under cover of your letter of January 3 I find the following entry:

"December 28 -- Visit from Miss Saunders, teacher of the Kincolith Indian day school, for advice having received no pay of any sort since her appointment to Kincolith day school in September."

Miss Saunders was nominated by Rt. Rev. Bishop Rix but although Indian Agent Collison was requested in our letter of October 4 and again in a letter dated November 8 to advise us the exact date on which she began duties he did not supply this information until November 12 on which date he wrote to the Department and his letter reached here on November 19. The Representative of the Treasury was immediately requested to issue cheque at the end of November in favour of Miss Saunders for her salary for the months of September, October and November. Cheque 41636 for $300.00 was forwarded to Miss Saunders on December 1, 1939. This cheque should have, and no doubt did reach her early in December. In addition cheque 4621 for $100.00 in payment of her salary for the month of December was mailed from here in time to reach Kincolith before the school closed for the Christmas holidays on December 21.

You will note from the above that as soon as the Department had definite information regarding the date on which Miss Saunders began duties arrangements

Major D. M. MacKay,

Vancouver, B. C.
were made to pay her for her services. As pointed out above she must have received the cheque for her salary for September, October and November and likely the one for December before meeting Inspector Barry on December 28 and under these circumstances I cannot see why she gave him the information contained in his diary.

Dear Major MacKay:

At your request I have given considerable thought to the question of the necessity for a second teacher at the Kincolith Indian Day School, Skeena River Agency, as outlined in Mr. Indian Agent Gillett's letter S-E-13076 of the 11th of July.

Miss Anne Saunders, an exceptionally fine teacher with many years experience, has explained the need for a second teacher for the months October to March inclusive during her visit to me this afternoon. There will be some sixty pupils in attendance and all Grades from 1 to 8 will be represented this next year. There is no doubt that for much of the six months mentioned above there will be some 50 pupils on the average in the schoolroom, and this is too much for any teacher when all Grades are represented.

I believe that it would be well to have a second teacher at Kincolith for the six months October 1st to March 31st and consider that such a teacher could take the older pupils in the council hall mentioned by Miss Saunders and Mr. Gillett. A suitable salary would be $90.00 per teaching month.

I do not consider that it would be necessary to provide desks or blackboard, and I consider that Mr. Gillett's estimate of $50.00 for fuel and $50.00 for janitor service might each be halved. I agree to his suggestion of $10.00 for stovepipe and sundry expenses and $60.00 for rent of the council hall.

The total expenses would therefore come to $650.00 for the present Fiscal Year, and I would ask that this sum be authorized if it can be found anywhere, though I must point out that there is no provision for it in the estimates.

May I ask that this matter be dealt with by air mail and telegram as Miss Saunders feels I believe unable to attempt the instruction of so many pupils by herself. She has carried out the wishes of the Department through a number of years and has herself increased the attendance at Kincolith by constant visits to the parents. I may say that the Kincolith parents are progressive and would much resent the idea of having the children attend on the Half Day System, which is my only alternative suggestion.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Dear Major MacKay:

With reference to Departmental letter 188-27-1 drawing attention to an entry in my diary for the month of December regarding a visit from Miss Saunders, teacher of the Kincolith Indian Day School, Skeena River Agency, I would submit the following explanation.

Mail is taken to Kincolith from Vancouver and Prince Rupert twice a month only. In December 1938 the Union S.S. Catala leaving Vancouver on December 15th, in which no doubt cheque #186C for $300.00 went north, went aground off the Skeena River before reaching even Prince Rupert. After a delay this S.S. Catala did get as far as Prince Rupert but did not go on to Kincolith some sixty five or seventy miles further north.

Mail for Kincolith, the Nass River in general and for further north was taken by a special and additional sailing of the Union C.S. Cordona leaving Vancouver on December 22nd. The cheques for Miss Saunders for the $300.00 and also $100.00 would have reached Kincolith on Monday December 26th by the Union C.S. Cordona.

As Miss Saunders explained it to me she did not appear to be able to obtain satisfaction from Indian Agent Collison by letters and so leaving Kincolith on December 21st on land by tug boat in a storm and then transferring to a tug boat at sea and at night arrived in Prince Rupert in time to see Mr Collison and take the C.N.R.S. Prince Rupert sailing for Vancouver on the evening of December 22nd.

Miss Saunders in her explanation to me said that Mr Collison had taken the matter of the non receipt of her salary up with the Department by telegram.

My advice to Miss Saunders was to the effect that if the matter had been taken up by telegram I was certain that the Department would rectify any mistake, and that she would probably find some $100.00 waiting for her on her return to Kincolith. I explained that it was not necessary for me to take the matter up with you. It was however mentioned in my diary to allow Mr Phelan to check up on the matter should he so desire.

Officials in Ottawa would not be aware of the accident to Union S.S. Catala the mail boat for Kincolith and as I wish to clear Miss Saunders of any unprofessional conduct, I have inquired into the matter with some care. I am not able to explain Indian Affairs' delay in forwarding the required information to the Department.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch,

Re:- Kincolith School.

With reference to your letter of June 21st relative to Inspector B. Thorsteinsson's report of the above school, I doubt that much improvement can be expected so long as the teacher is also the clergyman.

Referring to the low attendance, this matter was taken up with Reverend Norman Green when he called at the office recently, and every time I visited the school. He states emphatically that the children were not at the village but either at the canneries or elsewhere with their parents. It is true that since the Japanese left the Coast a number of Indians have been acting as watchmen at the various canneries, and a great number go to the canneries much earlier for repair work, sometimes as early as March, whereas before very few migrated until June.

There are forty-eight children at Kincolith who are of school age. According to Mr. Green's monthly reports, the highest number that were enrolled is 38. The average for the various months is listed hereunder:

Extract from Inspector Barry's report on the Kincolith Indian Day School inspected on May 13, 1940.

The present teacher, Miss Bartle, has been a complete failure here, and has now resigned of her own will. The Indians have for some time been very anxious to get rid of her. She was nominated by the Right Reverend Bishop Rix in the first place and had previous Provincial experience.

The question of Miss Bartle's loyalty to the British Crown was brought to my attention in Prince Rupert by those outside the Department. Questioned by me Miss Bartle admitted she was a Christian Socialist, but stated she was loyal to the Government of Canada. She admitted she had perhaps talked too much. One of her grandparents was a German and she was believed by a number of Prince Rupert people to have strong German sympathy. I explained to her that while the Department does not question the right of teachers to support any particular party in the House of Commons it does expect its servants to be loyal to Canada and the Crown.

Miss Bartle without any particular advice from me informed me that she had no intention of returning as she could not do the work here alone. I asked her to inform the Indian Agent of her decision, which she has now done.

As Miss Bartle has resigned there is little use making any further report on the unsatisfactory work done during the year. I hope that she will never again receive an appointment in any sort of Indian school. She had been most thoroughly informed by me of the work to be done in each Grade before she took up her appointment here, but she quite failed to carry out my wishes, mainly because she could not maintain control among either the older or younger pupils.

With reference to your letter of Sept. 8th, I wish to advise that there are 63 children of school age belonging to Kincolith who are scattered in various places.

At present there are 10 at Kincolith and there will be approximately 30 residing in that village after the fishing season. There are 15 new beginners of whom will be in Kincolith.

In checking over the quarterly returns for 1944-45, I find that there were 10 who attended practically all the time, 8 who attended half the time, 4 who attended less than half and 12 who attended only a few days.

Inspector's Report - Kincolith Indian Day School

Dear Bishop Gibson:

We have received School Inspector Davey's report upon his visit to the above school on February 12, 1947.

Inspector Davey comments as follows:

"The pupils who began attending school in the fall have learned little. They are not ready to start work on a Pre-primer. The only pupil in Grade I who shows any development of 'reading readiness' is a boy who is repeating the year's work.

"Pupils in the other grades are not able to attempt work of their grade level.

"The pupils were not clean on the day of my visit.

"This teacher finds the teaching too heavy with his Church and Post Office work. He is apparently trying hard but lacks the training and personality to be effective."

Major MacKay has further informed the Department that the work of Mr. Johnston at Kincolith is very unsatisfactory. Apparently, Mr. Johnson does not like teaching and finds the work too difficult with his other duties in connection with the Church and the Post Office.

You will probably recall that this is a repetition of our experience with the Reverend Mr. Green,

Rt. Rev. J.B. Gibson, D.D.,
See House,
Prince Rupert, B.C.
who was Mr. Johnston's predecessor. Therefore, the Department recommends that Mr. Johnston's services be terminated at the end of the present academic year.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Sir,

I have the honor to submit plans, specifications and bill of quantities for the erection of a school building at Kinkolith, Nass River.

A building such as that planned for is estimated to cost the sum of $2083.25.

Provision has been made for the protection of the building against the heavy snows which break down many buildings in the Northern country, as also for the essential light and convenience for the pupils.

Should the enclosed meet with the approval of the Department, I would point out that when making an advance on the cost of the building the lumber should be purchased all at once so as to secure a steamer to tow it all to its destination at once and thus save the Department the cost of shipping smaller quantities which would involve unnecessary delivery charges.

I may also say that the Venerable Arc-deacon Collison would be willing to oversee the work, but a competent foreman of works should be obtained to direct the building.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

"Please forward plans and specifications Kin-kolith School quickly to Metlakatla".

I think it will be possible to secure the services of the same man as undertook the building of the Fort Essington School, who is a splendid man. If he cannot be secured it may be possible to get another person from Prince Rupert or Port Simpson.

The rapid growth of the cities of the North make it rather difficult to get a thoroughly competent man for outside work, as provisions are expensive and wages no higher than in the city.

Ottawa, November 18, 1931.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Barry, in a report on his inspection of the Kincolith Indian Day School, states that some work may have to be done on the foundation of the school building in the near future. He also states that the toilets, one of which is off the woodshed, are in very poor condition and recommends the immediate construction of a large double toilet, with a partition in the centre, to be attached to the end of the present woodshed. He recommends that the toilets now in use be taken down and burned and the ground filled in. He also states that the interior of the schoolroom will require to be painted next year.

In connection with the Inspector's recommendations, I have to say that we will have no funds this year to carry out any of the above work. I shall be pleased, however, to have a report from you stating, in detail, the work required to the foundation, in the erection of new toilets and in painting the interior of the school. Please state the total cost involved, when consideration will be given to providing funds for the purpose in our Estimates for the next fiscal year.

The Inspector also states that there is a small leak in the roof of the school, but that this matter was pointed out to you at the time of his inspection. You may arrange to have the necessary repairs made, in order to prevent leakage, keeping the cost for the purpose as low as possible. When the work is completed, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

W. H. Collison, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Prince Rupert,
B.C.

Your obedient servant,

EXTRACT from Inspector Barry's Report on his visit to the KINCOLITH INDIAN DAY SCHOOL on October 10, 1931.

The buildings were constructed some 30 years ago. The school on the whole is in good repair. Some work may have to be done on the foundations in the near future. The toilets, of which one is off the woodshed, are in a very poor state indeed. I would recommend the immediate construction of a large double toilet with a partition in the centre. This building should be attached to the end of the present woodshed. The toilets now in use should be taken down, and burned, and the ground filled in. The inside of the schoolroom will need to be painted next year at a cost of about $75.00.

There is a small leak in the roof of the school. This matter was pointed out to the Indian Agent, who was with me during part of the inspection.

The nearest water supply to the school is about 100 yards away. There is no water supply at the school.

Sir:

With reference to the Department's recommendation in connection with Inspector Barry's report on the Kincolith Indian Day School, I beg to state that the cost of providing a new double toilet with board walk approach and pulling down the old ones, will cost approximately $100.00 to $125.00. As the lumber will have to be shipped from Prince Rupert it will add somewhat to the cost of freight and handling charges.

I suggested to Inspector Barry during his last visit to the school that when funds are available it would be advisable to have the whole interior of the school painted. The floor and wainscoting were painted two years ago. As the schoolroom is a large one measuring thirty feet by twenty-five feet, with ten foot walls and ceiling to be painted, it will cost approximately $75.00. This figure includes painting of two porches and bookroom.

Necessary repairs to the roof of the coal and woodshed which is attached to the main building and was damaged by the weight of snow last winter will cost $20.00 including material and I would recommend that this be done before the coming winter, making a total expenditure of $220.00 for repairs and painting.

With regard to the foundation of the school, there is no immediate necessity for repairs. The building is settling a little, but there is no structural weakness. The leak of the roof which was only a small matter has already been attended to. If the painting is authorized I shall be glad to hear from the Department as the work should be carried out before school opens.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Ottawa, August 10, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the third instant, giving an estimate of the cost of a new double toilet with board walk approach and of pulling down the old ones, at the Kincolith Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of your arranging for the erection of a double toilet, with partition in the centre, to be attached to the end of the present woodshed, or, if you consider this site not satisfactory, you may erect the toilet on a site convenient to the school. You should arrange for the purchase of all materials required from a firm on the list to receive consideration, and for forwarding same from Prince Rupert to the school. You should also arrange for the labour in the erection of the toilet. Indian labour should be employed as far as possible. Please give the necessary instructions regarding the size and type of the building, having in view the keeping down of the costs to the lowest possible point. The total amount for material, labour and freight on materials should not exceed your estimate of $125.

You may arrange to have the repairs absolutely required made to the roof of the coal and wood shed. It is noted you estimate the cost, including material, to be $20.

The Department has no funds this year to authorize the painting of the interior of the school, and this work will have to stand over until a later date.

After the work in the erection of the toilet and the repairing of the roof of the coal and wood shed has been completed, you should forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of all materials and also accounts, in triplicate, in favour of the individual labourers employed, covering the amount due them. Details should be given as to the days or hours employed and the rate of payment. Please have the above authorized work carried out at an early date.

With reference to the foundation of the school, it is noted that it is not in need of immediate repair.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, relative to the carrying out of alterations to the classroom of the Kincolith Indian Day School and giving an estimate of the cost of material and labour required.

In reply I have to say the Department will approve of an expenditure not exceeding $150 in making the alterations, including paint for classroom walls and floor. You should arrange for the purchase of the materials required, from firms on the approved list, and also for the labour. Indian labour should be utilized as far as possible. Please see that a satisfactory job is completed.

After the work has been finished to your satisfaction, you should forward accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred. Full particulars should be given regarding the labour - days employed and rate per day. This work should be carried out during the coming summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Referring to official letter of January 18th last, authorizing the carrying out of alterations to the class-room of the Kincolith Indian Day School, I beg to state that it was not possible to have the work done at the time as it would have meant closing the school for a period of about ten days when most of the children are attending school.

I shall be glad if the authority is renewed so that the work may be carried out during the summer holidays.

Ottawa, May 26th, 1937.

Dear Sir,-

Some time ago, I wrote a letter to teachers of all Indian day schools. A reply has recently been received from Miss Edith M. Aylwin, teacher of the Kincolith Indian Day School, in which she writes, in part, as follows:-

"I do hope there will soon be a playground for the children. The school lot is 200 feet long but it is covered all over by trees, bushes and dead brush. The children and I did as much towards cleaning it as our strength would allow but it was a hopeless task. A board walk runs through the grounds to a little platform in front of the door. This walk, in places three feet or more from the ground, is all the school playground for my 52 pupils unless they cross the creek or go off in front of the church.

"Then there is the problem of school wood. Could not this item be included in the yearly estimates and some provision made for it? It is hard to ask a man to wait months for his pay and often most inconvenient for the teacher to advance the money and wait months for a refund."

You might let me have an estimate of the cost of clearing sufficient ground at this school to make room for the children's playground.

The Department cannot understand the teacher's remarks regarding the wood. We are quite prepared to pay for the wood required at this school as soon as it is delivered. There is no reason why the teacher should have to pay for it and wait for a refund.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

W. E. Collison, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Prince Rupert, B. C.
Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated May 6th relative to the Kingolith Indian Day School, with particular reference to Miss Aylwin's remarks concerning the school playground, and school firewood.

With regard to playground facilities, the pupils at present play on an open space about 100 yards from the school. It would improve the appearance of the school grounds, as well as provide a playground which can be supervised from the school, if the land in front of the building was cleared.

For this purpose, I placed a sum of $50.00 in the estimates for the present fiscal year.

The cost of clearing the land all round the school will be approximately $300.00. A further grant could be made next year.

I would recommend that an expenditure of $50.00 be authorized immediately so that a start might be made during the summer months.

Regarding Miss Aylwin's remarks about payment for the school wood, I would state that all accounts are forwarded to the Department for payment as soon as they are received at this office from all teachers. The trouble is that as soon as wood is delivered the Indians want payment, sometimes asking for an advance. Owing to the fact that there was only a monthly mail service to Kingolith during the past winter there has been added delay which is unavoidable.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

I am forwarding Mr. Indian Agent Anfield's letters of October 29th and November 27th in connection with the proposed supply of a new heater for the Kincolith Indian Day School.

I may say that the necessity for the supply of a new heater for this school was questioned inasmuch as a new McClary Furnacette was provided in August, 1944, on the recommendation of the Indian Agent who apparently considered this model sufficiently large to heat the cubic capacity of the classroom, contrary to the statement made by Mr. Anfield. The information now provided by the Agent indicates, however, that a replacement is necessary and it is recommended that authority be granted for the purchase of a new heater at a cost of $69.50 and new stove pipes at a cost of $1.45.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Prince Rupert, B.C.
November 27th, 1946.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

Re yours of November 5th, file 215-8-5650, it is confirmed that a No. 17 McClary Furnacette was installed in 1944 at the Kincolith Indian Day School. It is considered that the reason this stove has deteriorated so rapidly is partly that it is a wartime model and also that it was too small to heat the cubic capacity of this classroom without being forced with consequent distortion of plates and walls.

To emphasize the need of this stove, I quote from a letter received this morning from Rev. George Johnston, teacher at this school which states "just a note re the school heater, which I hope will soon arrive because the old one is in very bad shape and very dangerous during this severe weather, which has greatly depleted our fuel supply." I am now informed that the oil burners previously procurable at War Assets have been sold and will not, therefore, be available. Gordon & Anderson of Prince Rupert have a much larger brick lined heater available for immediate purchase at $69.50. They have agreed to hold this heater for acceptance by return mail.

It is recommended that this be purchased for shipment on December 8th, the last boat to Kincolith before Christmas. In addition to the stove, authority is requested to purchase 10 lengths of 6" stove pipe @ 20¢ and 1-6" damper @ 25¢. In view of Mr. Johnston's further statement it is considered that this purchase is urgent and your instructions by return mail will be appreciated.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.
Prince Rupert, B. C.
October 29th, 1946.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C., Vancouver.

The stove at the Kincolith Indian Day School must be replaced immediately as it is in an unsafe condition. The sides are cracked from top to bottom and the grates are pretty well gone.

It is recommended that an oil burner be installed in this School immediately. A suitable oil burner can be purchased from the War Assets Corporation for $48.00 delivered at Kincolith. In addition to this 10 lengths of 6" stove pipe @ 20¢ and 1/6" damper @ 25¢ will be required. Authority to make these purchases is requested. Other repairs recommended at this School will form the subject of another communication. The installation of this stove is, however, urgent.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

Re: Kincolith Indian Day School

I have had a further exchange of correspondence with Supt. Anfield following his letter of October 25th attached and the information secured indicates that the condition of the above-mentioned school building is such that we may continue to use it for the balance of the academic year without undue danger of it collapsing providing minor repairs are carried out.

Mr. Anfield estimates that an expenditure of $100 for material and labour will be sufficient to meet the cost of these minor repairs and I would ask that an accountable advance be forwarded to him.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
This school was visited on October 16th and 21st, 1948. There are 38 pupils enrolled and attendance has been excellent since the people returned from the Canneries early this month. There is a new teacher at this School, Miss Kathleen Howe, B.A. She is doing very good work and there is every indication that the school will be filled to overcrowding within a month.

A careful inspection of the school building was made, particularly of the foundations, which are more than one fourth submerged in water. There are 28 posts supporting the building, which is well over 40 years old. Nine of these posts (12 x 12's) are rotted right through at the ground and are held up only by spikes in the upper joints. Rot in varying stages was noticed in about ten other posts. There is a dangerous lean on 16 posts at the rear of the building, at least 3 complete bents at a 10° angle. Actually, the building is being supported by an old lean-to woodshed on the lee side of the building, the roof of which has jammed under the eave of the main school roof, which is one-half pitch. It is my considered opinion that the building is unsafe for further occupancy without immediate bracing. I called the Council into session and they inspected the building with me and agreed to cut six trees and wedge them as braces against the lee or sheltered wall of the school at once.

The Council was asked if they would give us a building for use as a temporary school. They offered the Department the Council Hall rent free, if we would do the repairs required to make it usable as a school. The Hall is panelled and in good shape; inside measurements are 22 x 28 x 12 ft. with two small rooms suitable for cloakroom and supplies. The roof is in good shape, but without ridge boards.
Outside porch and steps are rotted off. With the following repairs, this could be a most suitable temporary classroom. It is, therefore, recommended that the following be purchased immediately, and the children moved into this building:

- Shingles, 1 sq. @ $12.50 for porch roof $12.50
- Flashings, aluminum, 40' x 24 inches $12.00
- Yukon chimney to fit 1/3 pitch roof $18.00

**Lumber**

- 12 pcs. 2 x 12 - 10 steps
- 3 pcs. 2 x 12 - 14 risers Delivered at
- 12 pcs. 2 x 12 - 8 porch floor Kincolith - 1160 $108.00
- 15 pcs. 2 x 12 - 12 (sidewalk to) ft. B.M. @ $90 M
- 12 pcs. 2 x 6 - 12 (toilets and)
- 100' lineal ft. 4 x 14 (to road)
- Shelving for stock cupboards, 100 lin. ft. 2 x 12

2 only single sash, glazed 24 x 30 @ 3.40 $6.80

**Nails**

- 5 lbs. shingle nails
- 50 lbs. ¼" common nails @ 20¢ lb. delivered $11.00
- 50 lbs. 2½" common nails

**Heating**

- Stove (coal or oil) to heat 7500 cut. ft. space $95.00
- One door, outside, 5 panel 36" x 84" x 1¾ with hdl. $8.75
- Stove pipes and wire, 1 roll each $3.00
- Coat hooks, 4 dozen, 4 dozen, brushed brass $8.00

**Labor**

Including emergency bracing of present building, moving of school desks and equipment; all repairs and construction of sidewalks to road and toilets; also placing of blackboards and erection of cupbds.
and shelving for stock and material - putting in new steps, porch, yukon chimney and flashing and ridge boards

3 carpenters, 40 hrs. a piece @ 95¢ an hr. 114.00

Total cost of conversion of the building as a classroom $397.05

It is recommended that this work proceed immediately and a signal to start is requested, as I would like to have it underway before I go on statutory leave next month.

A survey of the children due back at this village was made and I am convinced there will be in excess of 50 pupils at Kincolith by the end of the month, or as soon as the fall seining is over and the families now at canneries return. This will call for a two room school, and I believe that once we get the children out of the present building and brace the walls, temporary posts could be put under the structure and the front half of it used as a senior classroom for the balance of the school year. It is with this in mind that I would like a new stove put in the Council Hall. I am also prepared to move the blackboard from the Crosby Home at Port Simpson and save the cost of ripping out the present boards. I believe that it would take two weeks work for 4 men to put in mud sills, new posts and jack the building back into line for continued safe use on a limited basis.

I should also mention that the Missionary, Rev. George Johnston, and family, are leaving Kincolith in November. It is likely that the Bishop will handle ministrations at Kincolith by using the Mission boat and its travelling Clergyman for fortnightly calls for services. This would leave the Mission House available for rent by the Department. We could put two teachers in there comfortably. It would be unfurnished but perhaps furniture could be bought and later moved into the inevitable new school when constructed.

To sum up:

1. We have a building which must be vacated at once for safety's sake, but which could be made safe for a limited number of children at an estimated cost of $750.00 for labour and materials.
2. We have a building immediately available for conversion to a classroom so that classes may continue without hindrance.

3. We have approximately 40 children in attendance with a likelihood of 50 within a month and consequent need of two classrooms and teachers.

4. We have a certainty that accommodation for 2 teachers can be made available by the end of November.

It is, therefore, recommended:

(a) That the Council Hall be accepted and converted at once.

(b) That if the school population reaches 50, the present building be re-posted and jacked back into line and used as a second classroom.

(c) That an additional teacher be secured when the roll reaches 50.

(d) That arrangements be concluded to rent the Mission House as a teacherage and that it be furnished by the Department having in mind the needs of a new school in any case.

(e) That Kincolith be given priority for new construction of a two room school and teacherage.

(f) That if the second classroom is opened, primary tables and chairs be purchased for 36 children, instead of desks. These would be available for moving into the new school.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Superintendent.

Estimated load in this village is 40 K.W. at least.

In general, the Department is strongly advised to wire these schools and to make provision for the installation of 1000 Watt A.C. 110 Volt manually operated gasoline lighting plants in each school. In Indian villages, the community plants are only turned on in the late afternoon and run approximately to midnight. They are never operated in the mornings. During the winter months in our northern villages, even with school opening at 9:30 a.m., light is essential for at least an hour in the classrooms in the mornings and for at least the last hour in
the afternoons. With furnace heating, light would be required by the janitor as early as 7:00 A.M. in the winter months.

In Greenville and Hartley Bay, these plants could also provide power for radiophones which it is hoped may be installed in both villages to provide better communications for medical emergencies. Both these villages are pretty well isolated for three months each winter; Hartley Bay by storms and Greenville by freeze-up of the Naam River.

It is, therefore, recommended that the use of village plants for power for these schools be not considered, but that they be wired and equipped with their own lighting units. For your information, we have Oman lighting plants at Kincolith Nursing Station, Port Simpson Nursing Station, Kitkatla Nursing Station and Kitamaat Nursing Station; all operated successfully by women.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Superintendent.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Hartley Bay, Kiscolith and Lekalap Indian Day Schools.

Included in our Main Estimates for 1949-50 is the sum of $30,000.00 each for the erection of two-room schools and teacherages on each of the above reserves, in the Skeena River Agency, near Prince Rupert, British Columbia.

Whereas our day school building program has met with considerable success in the other provinces, we have encountered many difficulties in British Columbia. At Ucluelet, we advertised for tenders for the erection of a two-room school and attached teachers' residence and the lowest tender for standard construction was $2,612.00. This same school, we are having built in Saskatchewan for $29,000.00. As you are aware, we finally decided to erect a cement school at Ucluelet.

At Cape Mudge, we advertised for a one-room school with attached teacher's residence complete with electricity, plumbing, etc., we are having two such schools erected in Ontario for about $17,000.00. The one and only tender received for the erection of the Cape Mudge School was $29,744.75.

At Fort Babine, we advertised for tenders for the erection of a two-room Indian day school and teacherage but received one tender only, in the amount of $67,391.00.

Therefore, due to the scarcity of contractors bidding on our projects and the high prices tendered by them, our officials in British Columbia have come to the decision that prefabricated
schools should be erected on each of the above three reserves. Their decision in this regard has been aided by the satisfaction obtained from the company which erected the two-room school and teachers' quarters at Pemberton Meadows in the New Westminster Agency and the one-room school at Metlakatla in the Skeena River Agency. This company is Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 489, Vancouver, B.C., and I attach both the previous Order-in-Council covering the provision of the Pemberton Meadows School and photographs taken by Inspector Davy of the completed building.

Our officials are perfectly satisfied with these buildings and Mr. Indian Superintendent Anfield, who knows how to supervise the erection of this type of school from his experience at Metlakatla, makes the following statement:

"I am satisfied that it will wear well, operate economically and that the type of construction is suitable and most adaptable for the type of country in the Skeena Agency. The school has been viewed with considerable approval by the Provincial School Inspector, Mr. J. Shell, at Prince Rupert. It is recommended that two-classroom schools of this type, with teachers' quarters attached, be constructed at Hartley Bay, Greenville and Kincolith, with the least possible delay."

With regard to advertising for tenders, not only have we our previous disappointments as a guide, but Mr. Anfield makes the following statement:

"I have approached Messrs. Mitchell and Currie, Groer and Bridgen, both contracting firms of Prince Rupert and they refuse to bid on the construction of new schools at these three points, giving isolation of location and risk re transportation as the main reasons. These and other contractors in Prince Rupert have so much other work on hand that they are just not interested."

Mr. Indian Commissioner Arnell concurs in these recommendations and points out that these buildings can be erected at a cost to the Department considerably less than we could get a quotation from a contractor. In this regard he makes the following statement:
"You will note Mr. Amfield's reference to the need for employment at these Indian villages. Erection of these schools will provide some of that much-needed employment and in addition will ensure most urgently required classroom accommodation and, as previously pointed out, at a saving of several thousand dollars in each case."

The only other company in British Columbia producing schools of this type is Precision Housing Company, which produces pre-cut schools. These are much more difficult to erect with the type of semi-skilled Indian labour we will have available and are not recommended by our field officials.

Therefore, I have no hesitation in recommending to you for presentation to the Minister, the attached submission to Council covering the purchase of three prefabricated schools from Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 489, Vancouver, B.C., for erection on these three reserves in the Skeena River Agency. We have foremen-carpenters in mind and can employ the Indians who are fairly competent mechanics and carpenters, under white supervision, for the erection of these prefabricated buildings.

Director.

K.M.

Re: School Construction -
Skeena River Agency

With reference to Colonel Neary's army signal's message of January 16th, I am forwarding Superintendent Anfield's letter of January 21st, wherein he reports with regard to the foremen employed on the three school construction projects in his Agency and also details the progress made on each project.

We have experienced most extreme winter weather conditions in British Columbia during the past month and as construction could only be carried on at an exorbitant cost, it is felt that Mr. Anfield was wise in laying off the foremen temporarily.

We had originally intended to ship the first building to Greenville but the Neas River froze three days before the building arrived and consequently it was diverted to Kincolith and the building intended for Kincolith was shipped to Hartley Bay. The third building is ready for shipment from Vancouver.

There is some doubt as to whether or not we will be able to get to Greenville before the end of the fiscal year. You will be advised when work on these projects is resumed.

(sgd) W.S. Arneil
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Attached please find the following bids on plumbing installations on the three Indian Day Schools, this Agency, now under construction at Hartley Bay, Kincolith and Greenville.

1. Smith & Elkins Ltd., P.O. Box 274, City  
2. Saanich Plumbing and Heating Ltd., Box 1158 B, City

An analysis of these bids indicates as follows:

(a) Smith & Elkins' bid is for $1092.00 per school. It is presumed that the piping would be standard water pipe either black or galvanized. It is also noted that they bid on the supplying of a shallow well pump complete with motor and tank but do not indicate if their bid includes installation.

(b) Saanich Plumbing & Heating bid works out to $1092.42 per school, only 4¢ above the bid of Smith & Elkins. This firm however, plan to install all copper piping and joints. This is a decided asset as in all three of these schools, we will be inevitably faced with freeze-up conditions. Copper piping, which expands, will take care of a considerable lot of frost without splitting. This should be given due weight in apportioning these contracts. It is also noted that this firm will supply both the pressure tanks and pumps as well as the installation. From the above, it would appear that the Saanich Plumbing and Heating would give greater value for money received although it should be said that Smith & Elkins, which had the contract at our Metlakatla School, did a very nice job.

The Department's instructions as to these contracts will be appreciated. It is recommended that if possible, they may be let without delay so that material can be assembled and the rough work run in as soon as construction reaches a suitable point.

As you are aware, we are erecting three prefabricated schools at Kineolith, Hartley Bay and Lekalsap. Originally we had hoped to complete these projects by the end of the fiscal year but unusually severe weather has prevented this.

The buildings are now ready for wiring and Mr. Arneil has called for tenders for this work. An army message was received from him reading as follows:

In view of the information contained in Mr. Arneil's army message, I would recommend to you the acceptance of the lowest tender received from Rupert Radio and Electric, in the amount of $643.60 per school. Arrangements can be made for this work to be completed in early April.

Re: Kincolith Indian Day School

We have received your letter of February 28th with attached correspondence from Superintendent Anfield with regard to the expenditure that was incurred to repair the scow which was used on the Nass River to transport school material to the above school.

We have consulted the Treasury Branch and it is found that present regulations do not permit us paying the amount of $300.00. As a matter of fact, Superintendent Anfield had no right to even promise the amount without first receiving the Department's authority. Under these circumstances, we are returning unpaid Voucher 106.

Mr. Anfield's letter of February 27th reads in part as follows:

"The boat and scow were both chartered at $25.00 and $7.50 a day respectively. A crew of 4 men was hired to run the boat and scow, and were responsible for loading, transit and unloading. The men were hired at $10.00 a day per man."

The above is the first information we have received regarding the rate at which the boat and scow were chartered, and there is no mention of supplying gasoline, etc., for the operation of the boat. Mr. Anfield has submitted the following Vouchers for gasoline, grease, fuel oil and stove oil supplied the boat.
Voucher 214, $54.01. This account has been paid, although we should have had further information before doing so.

We have the following Vouchers for a similar expenditure which we have not paid:

- Voucher 317, $26.59
- Voucher 295, $35.67
- Voucher 333, $20.95

As there is nothing to show in Mr. Anfield's letter of February 27th that the Department was expected to supply the items mentioned on the Vouchers shown above, we cannot understand why he has submitted them to us. It would appear that these charges should be paid by the owner of the boat.

We would also like an explanation regarding the rate that the workmen are being paid. It appears from Credit Voucher 206 that they are receiving $1.00 an hour, and yet Mr. Anfield's Vouchers 305, 306, 313 and 329, amounting to $178.26 cover food supplies for the men. We would like Mr. Anfield's explanation why these Vouchers were forwarded for payment.

We also find it necessary to return Credit Voucher 206. On the first page of the labour return for the week ended January 7th, 1950, Henry Watts is shown to have worked 8 hours on January 4th and 3 hours on January 5th for a total of $11.00. On the second page of the labour return for the same week his name appears at the end of the list, and is again allowed wages for 8 hours for Wednesday, January 4th. It would appear that there was an $8.00 overcharge made to him.

Re: Scow Repairs.

Your letter of February 1st, 1950, file 12-11-3, pertaining to the above-named subject. The scow in question was rented from Matthew J. Stewart, Kincolith Indian, on a daily rate of $7.50. It was impossible to obtain insurance on the scow for use on the Nass River without a Marine survey and without the transfer or registration on this particular scow from the original owners. It is understood that Stewart purchased the scow from the Georgetown Lumber and Box Co. Ltd., but that the original scow registration was in the name of the original company which was later replaced by the present corporation, Georgetown Lumber and Box Co. Ltd., who had failed to re-register the scow in their own name. The transfer and any question of insurance was impossible - there being no Marine surveyor available in Prince Rupert.

There was urgency with regard to getting material up the Nass River in view of indicated weather conditions and I requested Stewart to proceed to the Nass River with building materials and gravel for delivery to Greenville. On this trip he ran into heavy icing conditions resulting in leakage to the scow to such an extent that on its return to Prince Rupert, immediate action was necessary to keep the scow afloat.

On the day that he returned to Prince Rupert, we were advised that the freighter carrying the Greenville school building was due here that week-end. The shipment required two large scows. We were able to procure a second scow through the courtesy of Armour Salvage & Towing Co. Ltd. and rather than unload half the school building and put it in storage resulting in consequent heavy charges for storage and reloading I rushed the Stewart scow on to the Drydock and had it put in usable condition at a cost of $928.44, $628.44 of which Mr. Stewart gladly consented to meet.
It is considered that in view of all these circumstances and the urgent need of getting this building from the freighter to the scow and up to the seas that that sum of $300.00 should be a charge on the Department rather than on Mr. Stewart. This statement is made having in mind that we requested additional work crews and over-time on the required repairs for our own use. Under normal circumstances, the scow could have been repaired for much less than the cost incurred for this particular work. It would, therefore, seem that the $300.00 could be charged as an additional charter on the scow and action along this line is recommended. It is considered that Mr. Stewart has more than paid the cost of repairs required for the scow under normal working conditions. I accept full responsibility for the extraordinary conditions that brought about the excess of cost over that met by Mr. Stewart for these repairs and consider that the Department is definitely responsible for the same.

Your further instructions will be appreciated.

[Signature]

F. Earl Amfield
Indian Superintendent.
Reference voucher no. 106 attached. The Department is advised that following the delivery of building materials and gravel to Greenville, the scow developed serious leaks necessitating immediate drydocking and repairs. The scow was rented by this Department from Mr. Matthew Stewart and after consultation with him it was agreed that he would pay $625.44 of the total amount and the Department would assume responsibility for the $300.00.

It was admitted by Mr. Stewart that the scow had been leaking prior to the initial charter but it is agreed that on the trip to Greenville with the heavy load of gravel the scow ran into heavy icing conditions which contributed to increased leakage. When the scow reached Prince Rupert, its condition was such as to render it unusable. In view of the fact that a freighter was due that week-end with the school for Greenville from Prefab Structures Ltd., the scow was immediately placed on the Drydock, repaired and relocated. There was no other scow available in Prince Rupert other than that of Mr. Stewart and another one chartered from Armor Salvage. We had to get the prefab building off the freighter on its arrival, without fail.

It is, therefore, recommended that this charge be met by the Department charged to the Kincolith School at which point the building finally had to be unloaded as by the time the scow reached there ice conditions in the Neas made it impossible to proceed further. Will you, therefore, issue a Purchase Order against the Prince Rupert Drydock and Shipyard and pass this account for payment.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Superintendent.

I am enclosing reports dated April 18th and 19th from Superintendent Anfield with regard to the funds required to complete the schools at Kincolith, Hartley Bay and Lakalsap.

You will note that in the case of the Lakalsap school, Mr. Anfield's original estimate will be exceeded by $12,000.00, Kincolith by approximately $2,500.00 and that the Hartley Bay school may be completed for somewhat less than his original estimate. The increased cost at Lakalsap can be attributed largely to the late start made on the project and the extreme winter which was experienced.

You will note that for the completion of these three projects an amount of $47,000.00 will be required. We would like to be advised as soon as possible of the amounts specifically provided this year for school construction so that unless it is intended to secure additional funds through supplementary estimates, transfers can be recommended.

Re: School Construction Projects

Re yours of April 12, 1950 herewith please find estimated further financial requirements for the Kincolith school under construction in this Agency.

Heating contract estimate - $2500.00
Plumbing contract estimate (including room and board of men employed) - 1500.00
Purchase and installation of lighting plant - 1000.00
Freighting and incidentals - 500.00
Labour, 250 man days @ 15.00 per day, including bd. and room as from April 1/50 to end of job. - 3750.00

Total estimated amount to complete job: $9250.00

Of the estimated labour cost of $4250.00 including freighting and incidentals, we have expended from April 1, 1950 to date the sum of $2403.93 by debit on Indian Agency Trust Account. This sum is repayable to Agency Trust and is therefore included in the labour requirements to complete the job at the School.

An accountable advance in the sum of $4000.00 has already been requested for labour and freighting on the project. This is urgently needed as we are compelled to pay wages two weeks and I am not happy about debiting Agency Trust for these sums. Will you please endeavour to have this advance and those requested for the other schools sent forward immediately and most
certainly not later than the end of the present month.

For your information the labour cost on the Kincolith job to March 31st was $9250.00. With the $4250 now requested, this should indicate a total labour cost, including all boat and scow hire, and freighting paid from Indian Agency Trust Account, of $14,500.00.

The voucher cost of materials to April 15, 1950 is $17,835.56 which includes cost of the building, freight thereon to Prince Rupert, all material, including cement, gravel, lumber etc., and all food supplies and camp equipment. This sum plus $5000.00 additional for subcontracts on heating, plumbing and lighting plants gives a total voucher cost of $22,835.56, making with labour added a gross cost on the job complete of $37,335.56.

As you may wish to send this breakdown in duplicate to Ottawa, I am attaching two carbon copies of this letter. My estimate on the job complete was $35,000.00

B. Earl Anfield

The river became impossible and the crew were stranded there for a month. It took a major operation to get them out. I also failed in estimating to give due weight to the difficulty in freighting up this river. The Greenville job was the first one we tackled using a white foreman and Indian labour. It proved a costly experiment. We then put the white crew in and got caught with the worst winter on record.

The crew is now on the way back in to complete this job. It is still hoped that we may make up part, at least, of this deficit over the estimated cost; every effort will be made to do so.

Re: Advance for labor, School Construction, Skeena River Agency.

Work on the schools at Greenville, Kincolith and Hartley Bay has been proceeded with since April 1st., in anticipation of the Department making funds immediately available for the payment of wages.

I wrote you on April 12th. and asked for an accountable advance of $4,000.00 for each of the three projects and have been in communication with you by Signal Message since then.

I am under the impression that Mr. Anfield in order to retain the services of his crews has had to arrange with the bank to carry the payrolls. Is there no way by which an advance of funds to Mr. Anfield for these projects can be expedited?

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Generating Plants - Hartley Bay, Kincolith and Greenville Schools.

Under date March 31st, I forwarded you quotations on the above mentioned units and recommended that the orders be placed with Electric Power and Equipment, 1285 Homer Street, Vancouver.

Contracts for wiring these schools have been let and it is essential that delivery of the generating units be made in the near future. In any case it is necessary that we know almost immediately if the plant quoted upon by Electric Power and Equipment is to be purchased so that the blocks can be constructed while we have labor, cement and concrete mixers at the schools.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
