Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Hartley Bay Indian Day School,
Kincolith Indian Day School,
Lekalasep Indian Day School,
Skeena River Indian Agency, B.C.,
Electoral District of Skeena.

Construction of the above buildings has proceeded to the point where it is essential that arrangements be made immediately for heating installations.

Indian Superintendent F.E. Anfield has obtained the following tenders for the installation of heating systems in the above three schools.

1. Shenton's Sheet Metal Works, Prince Rupert, B.C. $4,350.00
2. G.H. Tomlinson, Prince Rupert, B.C. $5,970.00
3. Thom Sheet Metal Ltd., Prince Rupert, B.C. $6,564.76

Mr. Robinson, the engineer attached to the office of the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia, has reviewed the tenders and considers that the lowest one will meet the requirements of the three schools mentioned above. Indian Commissioner Arnell recommends acceptance of the tender of Shenton's Sheet Metal Works in an amount of $4,350.00 and I would appreciate it if the Minister would approve.

Recommended

Director.

Deputy Minister

Re: Hartley Bay Day School
Kincolith Day School
Lakelsap Day School
Your File 168/6-1

We are in receipt of your letter of the 3lst ultimo with reference to the demolition of the old schools on the above sites. It is noted that the Indian Council have agreed to remove the old school building at Hartley Bay and rebuild it as a Council Hall, and that there will be no expenditure in this connection as far as the Department is concerned.

With reference to the old buildings at Kincolith and Lakelsap, it is noted that the amount of $600.00 will be required at the former school and $400.00 at the latter in order to tear the buildings down. It is presumed that Indian labour will be used, and consequently, the expenditure is approved.

We also note that you recommend transfer of an additional $1,000.00 from the appropriation for the Joint School at Port Harrison, to meet the cost of the work authorized in this letter.

Bernard F. Neary,

Dear Sir:

I herewith acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 18th Inst enclosing cheque for £46.50 for which I thank you.

I should like to ask the Department through you for an explanation the amount being so small. I am aware that it is required that the school should be open 216 days at least in the year. That however is not always possible here as the year 1906 shows.

In the first place there are two reserves which are some 30 miles apart. Considerable time is lost in moving for one cannot leave at will there being only one monthly steamer. Then again last year these people spent the fairly long periods at Alert Bay. I followed them and held school there but there was time lost however in moving. Then there are away at the canneries in the fishing season for the greater part of two months and in the fall they are away fishing for their fall salmon three weeks. Thus it will be seen that under these conditions that it is impossible to keep school open for the stipulated time.

Trusting this will receive your attention

I am yours respectfully,

Herbert Pearson

Sir:

I have the honor to inform you that at the beginning of the present quarter, Rev A.J Hall, of Church Missionary Society, made two changes in the teaching staff of the Indian Schools, in the part of this Agency over which his vicarage extends.

Mr Frank S. Ford, has retired from the work in B.C. and Mr Hall for some time could not get anyone to take the position. Finally he thought best to appoint Frank Nelsen, a native, to the position. Before doing so he came to this office and talked the matter over. This is for the Alert Bay Day School. I informed him that the Department on the whole was opposed to native teachers but that unless the Department objected that he might try and see what he could do. Since then I have called at the school every few days and have watched closely, but have been unable to find any fault. He has a much better attendance than the school has had since my tenure of office here, and the children are learning quickly. So far they are in the primary classes, but Nelsen should be able to bring them on at least to the fourth standard.

Mr Fred HENRY Gemley, has succeeded Mr Herbert Pearson at the Gwayasdums Day School. Mr Gemley is a young Englishman with a missionary spirit, and a splendid worker. I have not been able to visit his school yet as during my visit to Kingcome Inlet, it was Saturday, and school was not in session.

Dear Dr. Scott,

I have been intending to write to you for some time on various matters concerning the Indians of the district in which I am working.

We are building a school in the Kingcome Indian Village. It is quite a good building, capable of holding all the children of the village, and also, on occasion, the Indians at their gatherings.

The Diocese of New Westminster gave us $500.00 towards it, the Indians are going to raise $300.00, and the balance I have to get elsewhere. It will cost about $250.00. I am writing to you to ask you if you will help us out in this respect.

The schools in the village, I am more convinced than ever, are absolutely necessary in order that the new school may have its proper quota of children from those villages. Already it is very evident that the work of these school has added a large number of pupils to the Alert Bay Boarding School, and in the future I think their work will be necessary, as I said, to keep the big school going.

Last year you were kind enough to help us start the school at Fort Rupert by a grant of $40.00 per month. We obtained a teacher who knew the language and who did very good and important work in starting the school, but $40.00 a month is not quite enough when she is supplying the school house as well, and

Sir:

While Captain Barry, Department School Inspector and myself were paying an official visit to the Indian Day School at Kingcome village, it was made known to us that the teacher, Miss L.K. Solomon, would be leaving at the end of the present term as her sister who is the missionary-nurse there has accepted a position elsewhere.

REPORT ON KWAWKWEWLTH AGENCY FOR MONTH OF MARCH 1937.

The day schools at Campbell River, Cape Mudge, and Alert Bay are in splendid shape and a real credit to the Department, while the Missionary schools at Village Island, Kingcome Inlet, Quatsino and Smiths Inlet which were built by various Missions with assistance from the Department are in fair state of repair, they are difficult to administrate. I feel the Department should own these schools and have full administrative powers as the buildings are on reserves. I would recommend if and when funds are available the Department should purchase any equity the Missions may have in these buildings to avoid any future complications which may arise between the Indians and interested parties.

M.S. Todd,
Indian Agent.
The Kingcome Inlet Day School is also a Mission School built by the Church of England. It serves the four Kingcome tribes. The progress made here is very satisfactory, our main difficulty being in keeping the children at school. There are 40 pupils on the roll who should attend regularly. I would draw the Department's attention to the average for the quarter ending December 31st, 1936, which is 15.88. The quarterly return for March 31st has not as yet been received but the average undoubtedly will be lower still. This location for a village is against the best interests of the Indians and has been reported to the Department on several occasions. The poor average is caused through the Indians leaving the village and wintering at Gwayasdums Reserve where there is no school. It is a modern, up-to-date school.

M. S. Todd,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

On previous occasions I have reported to the Department the undesirability of the Kingcome village becoming a permanent village owing to annual floods during the freshet.

Recently I have been advised by the teacher at Kingcome they had six feet of water all around the village and that it was necessary for them to use a rowboat when going from place to place. I am informed no damage was done, and I can only account for this through the fact that the houses are built on posts sufficiently high for the water not to enter and destroy all their effects. I understand, however, quite a lot of food was destroyed during the flood.

This letter is being written with the specific purpose of my views being on record as to the unsuitability of this location for a village. I have suggested to the Indians that a more suitable location should be found as I am afraid sooner or later serious damage will result.

Yours obedient servant,

Dear Major MacKay:

I have read a letter from Mr. Todd, Indian Agent, Kwawkewlth Agency, with regard to the salary being paid to Miss P.M. Arrowsmith, the teacher of the Kingcome Inlet Indian Day School in his Agency.

While I am not able to say as Mr. Todd does that Miss Arrowsmith is "a very wonderful person and a splendid teacher" I do consider that she has made a success of her work at the Kingcome Inlet School.

Owing to the fact that Miss Arrowsmith was herself educated in a private school, and for some years taught in such schools, she had great difficulty in adapting herself to conditions in the Kingcome Inlet Indian Day School. Her technique has improved greatly during the past two years.

Miss Arrowsmith has arranged for a Kindergarten Class for pupils between the ages of four years and six years. These children are taught for a shorter time daily than the older pupils.

As Miss Arrowsmith only holds a Second Class B.C. Certificate I do not consider that she should be given the same status as that given to our teachers holding a First Class Certificate. The facts relating to the nature of the certificate held are ignored by Mr. Indian Agent Todd, who bases his argument on the number of pupils taught. In general the teachers in Indian Day Schools holding a First Class Certificate receive either $90.00 $95.00 or $100.00 per teaching month.

Miss Arrowsmith shares the Mission House with the Missionary Nurse. During January and February 1938 no classes were held as the children were out of the village as reported on April 8th, 1938 in my last report on the school. From March 2nd to the end of March 1938 the Kingcome Inlet Day School was only open for seventy-six days in all.

Miss Arrowsmith mentioned the subject of increased salary when I saw her last but I discouraged her making a definite application at that time, pointing out that she had a share of the Mission House, in addition to her pay, which was certainly worth something. I stated that in most cases teachers receiving a greater salary had to pay for house accommodation.

I do not however wish to negative Mr. Todd's recommendation that Miss Arrowsmith be given $900.00 per annum and shall content myself by recommending that not more than $90.00 be paid Miss Arrowsmith per teaching month in future. This will make it possible to run the school on an eight month year should such a course be found necessary later.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Inspector of Indian Affairs

Dear Major MacKay:

At your request I have considered with some care Departmental letter 156-17-1 of May 25th and attached correspondence.

As Mr. Indian Agent Todd has submitted his recommendations with regard to the future operation of certain Indian Day Schools in the Kwawkewlth Agency direct to the Department and as the Department has seen fit to reply directly to Mr. Todd, I cannot help but feel that I have been placed in an awkward position. However, as you request my suggestions, I would recommend as follows:

As the Indians do not return to Village Island until quite late in the year, I would recommend that Mamalilikulla Indian Day School be operated from January 1st to May 31st yearly. This would place the school definitely in the category of a part-time school and would, incidentally, save the Department the teacher's salary for three months for at present authorization has been given for an academic term lasting from November 1st, 1940, to June 30th, 1941.

A report on the conditions at this school is given on page 6 of my Survey Report On Small Indian Day Schools, dated January 6, 1940. My main reason for recommending that this school be put on a part-time basis is that there is a very small average attendance except, perhaps, between January 1st and May 31st yearly.

Owing to the small attendance in September and June, I consider that the Quatsino Indian Day School should only be operated from October 1st to May 31st yearly. Authority is at present given by the Department for this school to operate from October 1, 1940, to June 30, 1941. Should my suggestion be followed, you would save the salary of the teacher for one month at this school.

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.
On page 7 of my Survey On Small Indian Day Schools I pointed out that in June last all the Indians had moved away from the village.

With regard to the Kingcome Indian Day School, the present decision to operate the school on a six months basis from January 1st to June 30th is, in my opinion, quite satisfactory, though even here it might have been better to operate from January 1st to May 31st yearly as has been recommended in the case of the Mamalilikulla Indian Day School.

The Campbell River and the Cape Mudge Indian Day Schools are located quite near to one another and might well be treated in the same way. At present authorization has been given for the Campbell River school to be opened from October 1, 1940, to May 31, 1941. The attendance during the month of June at these schools is, in most years, quite low and I would recommend that in the case of both the Campbell River and the Cape Mudge Indian Day Schools the authorized academic term be from October 1st to May 31st yearly.

Should my suggestions as outlined above be followed, a considerable saving in teachers' salaries could be effected. The case of the Alert Bay Indian Day School is, however, in an entirely different category. The B.C. Packers Ltd. intend to operate their cannery at Alert Bay this year. This cannery has been closed for a number of years. The result will be that during the months of July, August and September a very large number of children, pupils of the Kingcome Inlet and Mamalilikulla included, will be at Alert Bay.

At Alert Bay Indian Day School the present authorized term is from October 1, 1940, to June 30, 1941. While this is a perfectly satisfactory arrangement, I would strongly recommend that during the months of August and September 1940, Alert Bay Indian Day School be operated as a two Division Summer School, the teachers being paid their usual monthly salary. If the Department follows my suggestions with regard to the other schools in the Kwawkewlth Agency, there will no doubt be more than sufficient funds saved on their operation to finance the suggested Alert Bay Summer School.

Yours very truly,

When the Indians are at home, the school has always had a good attendance and been successful, but on account of there being no means of livelihood for the Indians at Kingcome, they must leave there and go on their traplines or dig clams from the time the fishing season is over until the New Year and has resulted in very poor attendance, in fact two years ago there were very few children in the village until after the New Year. Quite a number of these children will be in Alert Bay living with their parents and will be going to the Alert Bay Day School, and I do not believe it would affect the children's education very much if this school was not opened until January 1st of each year. I would therefore recommend that the Kingcome School open on the 1st of January and remain open until June 30th."

In view of this information we are advising him that the Department approves the school operating from January 1 to June 30, 1941. If, however, you are aware of any reason why we should change this decision please let me know.

I enclose copy of Departmental letter to Indian Agent Todd.

Yours truly,

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,

Vancouver, B. C.

Dear Sir,

It has been brought to my attention that the Department's notice has been called to the fact that I closed the Kingcome Indian Day School ten days before the expiring of the term in June 1940 and I deemed it advisable to place you in possession of the facts of the case, particularly in view of the proposal that I be transferred to the Lakelsep Indian Day School.
Prior to my closing the Ringcome school every Indian of the village had left there and proceeded to their fishing grounds and the nurse and myself were left alone. Consequently there was no point in carrying on the formality of opening and closing the school for the remaining ten days. It was impossible to inform the Indian Agent to secure his permission as, owing to lack of mail connection, it would have taken five weeks to receive a reply, by which time the term would have expired. I could not call on him on my way out as the S.S. "Venture" calling at Ringcome does not touch at Alert Bay. Consequently I could only inform him in the usual way by my Quarterly Report and reference to this will show that I did so. My explanation has been made, in person, to both Captain Barry and Inspector Cotman.
It is very much regretted that this incident has reflected on my attention to my teaching duties but it will no doubt be obvious that I have no control over the movements of the Indians and the seasonal run of fish and the futility of my remaining in a deserted Indian village would be quite apparent.

I trust this explanation is satisfactory and that I will receive an appointment to the Lekaleap Indian Day School in the near future.

It would be appreciated if you would kindly advise the Indian Commissioner for B.C. by air mail.

Trusting you will give me the opportunity to continue to teach the Indians,

I am

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

On February 16th last, I visited Kingcome Inlet Mission, and as requested in your letter of January 30th, file 15-6-68, I beg to make the following report.

I was informed by Mrs. Massey, the teacher of the Kingcome Inlet Day School who arrived at Kingcome on January 1st that there were only two children in the village, who had only recently arrived, and that she had not thought it worth while holding school. On February 17th she wrote me stating she had started school and had three pupils.

Since then I have visited Gwayamsdums Reserve where the Kingcome Indians are now living, and upon making enquiries was informed it would be near the end of March before all the people would have returned to Kingcome. They stated the odd family might return previous to this but that the band would not all be there until the end of March. This will give us only a little over two full teaching months at this school as it closes on May 31st.

It is difficult to make recommendations in respect to this problem at Kingcome. As the Department is aware, I have previously recommended that the Kingcome village should be located at Gwayamsdums Reserve, and from our experience this year it would appear that eventually this will have to be done. Each year the Indians go to Gwayamsdums and locate there while they are digging clams and on their traplines, and I can see no change from this procedure in years to come.

In my opinion, a conference should be held between the Indians concerned, the Columbia Coast Mission and the Department sometime this spring with a view to definitely arriving at a decision as to the future. To move them from Kingcome to Gilford Island will cost considerable, but I think it is the only solution to this problem. I should like to see the Tsawataineuk, Ahwaniam and Kwicksutainseuk Band all located at Gilford Island, Gwayamsdums Reserve, and a proper village established there. They have a good water supply, a splendid townsite, native food, plenty of fuel, and a good harbour for their boats, but before anything could be done it would be necessary as stated above to hold a conference as suggested. I believe the Columbia Coast Mission would look favourably upon this, although it would mean the Mission being transferred from the Diocese of New Westminster to the Diocese of British Columbia, which in my opinion, would be a good thing.

Your obedient servant,

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Agent

Dear Mr. Greene:

I have to refer to your letters of December 3rd and 17th and our recent conversation regarding the possible re-opening of the Indian Day School at Kingcome Inlet.

This matter was discussed yesterday with Mr. Indian Agent Todd who suggested that it would be well to re-open the school provided a sufficient regular attendance could be assured. You might, therefore, let me have at your earliest convenience a nomination of a qualified teacher to take charge of the school early in the new year, when the whole subject will be submitted to the Department for consideration.

It is not known whether funds have been provided in the current year's Estimates for a seasonal school at Kingcome Inlet nor can any assurance be given that the Department will provide the necessary funds, in view of what occurred last year. I might also add that should the Department approve of the re-opening of the school, it would be definitely a seasonal school of not more than a five month term. The Department will also reserve the right to close the school without previous notice once the attendance does not justify its continuance.

With special reference to your letter of December 17th, I may say that the establishment of a school for Indian children at Kingcome Inlet to be operated purely under the Anglican Church auspices would require previous Departmental approval and I cannot give any assurance at the moment that this would be forthcoming.

Dear Major Mackay:

Replying to your letter 15/6/5671 dated December 19th and addressed to Mr. Greene, I am glad to read that you and Inspector Barry, as well as Mr. Todd, the Indian Agent, are prepared to recommend to Ottawa that the Indian Day School at Kingcome Inlet be reopened for this coming term ending May 30th or thereabouts.

Mr. Greene has informed me that every effort he has made to date, both in the Province and in Eastern Canada, has failed so far as securing a certified teacher is concerned, and he also informs me that in his considered opinion we might well nominate Mr. E.W. Christmas of "Mink Lake Farm", Margo, Sask., for the position, in spite of the fact that Mr. Christmas is not, nor never has been, a teacher. Mr. Greene, from correspondence with Mr. Christmas and references he has secured regarding him, ventures to offer the following comments in support of his recommending to me that as an alternative, Mr. Christmas be nominated as the teacher.

"First of all, everything in the correspondence goes to show that Mr. Christmas is a man of excellent moral character, judging from his reputation in Moose Jaw, Sask., up to the year 1930, and his subsequent career as a farmer near Margo, Sask.

Secondly as to his general ability. The correspondence again suggests a man of culture and good education, but as far as we at present know, his schooling ended in the Gravesend County School, Kent, England, but his gifts are varied in that he is a keen agriculturist, and is eager to encourage the development of self-supporting Indians at the Kingcome Indian Reserve along the lines of intensive gardening. He is a carpenter and wood-carver,"
and apparently a very capable craftsman in that direction. He has also considerable musical talent, being the organist in his parish church at Moose Jaw for some three years. He served also as Choir Master and Vestry Clerk, and was very keen about work amongst young people. He was fifty years of age on June 23rd 1941, and would be taking his wife with him to the Mission. She again is keenly interested in Social Welfare work and practical nursing, and between the two of them I believe they would make a very fine contribution to the general well-being of the Indians at Kingcome."

I have written him, subject to your readiness to accept a non-certified teacher, asking him if he would be prepared to undertake the teaching in the Kingcome Day School, advising him that the attendance would range anywhere from ten to twenty-five and possibly more at its peak, with the lower grades predominating."

Mr. Christmas, in one letter to Mr. Greene, wrote - "I have not of course trained for teaching school (but) I know, from frequently having been told so, that I have some gift as to clarity, patience and so on, as a tutor, practical and theoretical, in such widely differing subjects as agriculture, carpentry, and elementary orchestral work. I have always been keen on cricket and football, as well as indoor gymnastics".

Mr. Greene and I have given the matter careful thought, and in view of the seeming impossibility of getting a certified teacher, I recommend Mr. Christmas as the nominee for the position of teacher, trusting that his letter or telegram, which should arrive by Saturday noon of this week, will confirm his readiness to tackle this important work.

I might add that Mr. Christmas is prepared in the summer months to move with the Indians to cannery centres such as Glendale, Knights Inlet, and to carry on with social, educational and evangelistic work there, so as not to lose contact or continuity in his work with the Indians during their long three month's absence every summer.

Trusting you will give this nomination your favourable consideration, I remain,

Faithfully yours,

ADG/VS.

"Francis C. O. Heathcote".
Bishop of New Westminster.

Number of pupils on Register - 35
Average attendance - 22.75

Under the circumstances, I consider the average attendance as fair, although there is much room for improvement.

On March 16th last I visited this school, and was favourably impressed with Mr. Christmas, the teacher in charge. He has a son fourteen years old who was assisting him in the classroom. The pupils appeared happy and contented; they were clean and responsive, and the discipline was good. I was of the opinion progress was being made, and that even though Mr. Christmas is not a qualified teacher, the opening of the school was worthwhile.

Mr. Christmas' presence in the village no doubt is an asset to the Department, and although I am opposed to unqualified teachers being employed, nevertheless when it is impossible to get teachers, I feel under the circumstances this school should be continued under its present arrangement provided the Indians agree to return to school on the date set for the opening. Some time ago a petition was forwarded to your office from the Indians requesting that the school be reopened on October 1st next. I feel, however, that this date is too early, as the families will not be able to leave the canneries by that time. I would therefore recommend that the Kingcome Day School be reopened on November 16th next, to continue until May 31st, 1943.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

Replying to the first paragraph of your letter of March 16th last, file 318-6-3097, I beg to submit herewith the following report on the Kingcome Inlet Indian Day School.

I inspected this school on February 26th and again on March 1st, and regret very much that I cannot make a favourable report, particularly when every effort has been made to keep the school open under adverse conditions.

I found the classroom dirty, with paper and refuse lying all over the floor; the children were untidy, and there was no discipline whatever in the school. Insofar as an academic inspection is concerned, I have no comments to make as we have a School Inspector who will, I hope, be visiting this school in the near future and this phase of the work is left entirely to him.

The children looked very tired, their eyes bloodshot, with the appearance of having very little sleep. This no doubt was due to them sitting up all hours of the night attending the Indian Custom dances which were going on at the time of my arrival. A separate report in respect to these activities is being made, so I will not make any further mention of this in this report.

I found that the teacher, Mr. E.W. Christmas, had been having difficulty with the parents as well as with the children. Some pupils were absent from school through this. I interviewed the parents, and had no difficulty in getting matters adjusted, and the children are now back in school, but I believe the Indians themselves realize that Mr. Christmas is not an experienced teacher, and therefore he is not getting the support from the Indian people that he otherwise might.

In my opinion, Mr. Christmas has not got what it takes to be a teacher; he is tactless, and forever scolding and nagging until the children have reached the point where they pay no attention to what he says. It is possible that the discipline at the school may improve, as I made it very clear as to what was expected both from the teacher and the pupils.

The attendance at the school has been generally fair, although the register showed children present when I learned they had attended only a portion of the day; this was explained and adjusted so that the register shows the two half-day periods and attendance at each.

Apart from the fact that the carryings on of the Custom this winter has made it awkward and difficult for the teacher, nevertheless I must recommend that a change be made not later than the end of this term; had it been possible to obtain the services of another teacher at once I would have recommended that a change be made immediately, as I felt the situation was so serious.

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Agent
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

On receipt of this letter, I communicated with Rt. Rev. Sir F.C.C. Heathcote of New Westminster, under whose diocese the school is situate, advising that according to the Indian Agent Mr. Christmas was not making the success of his work that was expected and that it was suggested that he be replaced at the end of the present term but before referring the matter to you his comments would be appreciated. I have since received a call from the Bishop who objected to the release of Mr. Christmas at the expiry of the present term on the grounds that a poor teacher was better than none at all, a view with which I do not agree, as amongst other reasons, it prevents the employment of a more qualified teacher for the school in question.

Following the receipt of this letter, I endeavoured to have the school visited by the Provincial School Inspector for the district, but as Kingcome Inlet is not on the regular course of travel by the coastal boats, it will be impossible for him to get in to the school until the fall. Meanwhile, the only recommendation that I am prepared to make in the matter, apart from discontinuance of Mr. Christmas' services, is that his re-employment be contingent on his taking a course of summer school training at Victoria during the present year and subsequent evidence of more satisfactory handling of the Kingcome School.

Representative of the Treasury.

Re: School No. 818.

It has been decided to include the Kingcome Inlet Indian Day School on the regular monthly paylist from November 1st, 1935. However, as no payment of salary has been made to the teacher for the month of October, she is entitled to two months' salary on the November paylist, as follows:

Inlet, B.C.
Ottawa, November 5th, 1935.

Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 26th ultimo, I beg to say that, in view of your recommendation, the Kingcome Inlet and Quatsino Indian Day Schools will be placed on the paylist and the salaries of the teachers will be paid monthly beginning with the month of November.

As soon as you inform me regarding the exact date on which the teacher of the Campbell River Indian Day School begins duties, her name will also be placed on the monthly paylist.

The paylist has to be prepared early in the month. For instance, officers of the Schools Branch have to give authority about the 7th of November in order to have the name of a teacher included on the November paylist. It is, therefore, necessary for us to know definitely early in the month whether or not any school will be in operation for that month. From the information contained in your letter, it is doubtful if you can give us such assurance regarding the Namaliklikulla Indian Day School and, consequently, the Department is not prepared to place this school on the regular monthly paylist. I feel that it would be preferable to only pay this teacher when returns are received. By this method, all chances of making a mistake will be avoided. The same applies to the Smith's Inlet School.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

M. S. Todd, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Alert Bay, B. C.

Agent's Report on the School House at Gwayi

Alert Bay 19th May 1896

On the 12th of this month I inspected the new school building recently erected by the Rev. A.J. Hall at Gwayi Kingcome Inlet.

I found the building finished with the exception of one coat of paint inside and the front door.

The work has been well done, and the contract carried out exactly.

The only thing to be regretted is that the foundation was not placed upon mud sills instead of posts, as I found that the building had settled quite four inches, and as the ground upon which it is built, is liable to overflow from the river once each year, it is quite possible that the building will settle more, as the ground is of a very sandy nature, as is all the soil in the vicinity of the Village.

P.H. Pidcock
Indian Agent.
Specifications for a school house to be erected at the Indian Village of Gwagi Heycome Sault.

Foundation:
This building is to be forty feet long by twenty feet broad and to rest on three cells six by eight inches. There shall be not less than four cedar posts resting on the ground and corner corner of the building to be four feet from the ground. These posts to be not less than ten (10) inches in diameter. The posts are to be 2 x 8 inches and placed 24 inches apart from centre to centre.

Frame:
The height from the top of floor to top of wall plate shall be eleven feet with studding 2 x 4 in 2 feet centres. Each corner to be well braced by setting in pieces 2 x 4 having a run of not less than eight feet.

The rafters shall be of 2 x 6 scantling 2 ft centres having 12 inches projection. The length of the rafters to be sixteen feet 6 inches. There shall be a collar tie of 1 x 6 in well fastened which shall allow a run of three feet from the plate. These collar ties shall act as ceiling joists.

Windows and doors:
There shall be six windows and one door in all. Three of these windows to be facing the
river two on the end facing the Indian Village and one on the other end. The door shall be on the end near the Village and shall be protected by a small porch 6 feet square.

A small bell tower is to be erected on this side of the roof on the end near the Village to be at least 3 feet above the ridge of the building.

The building shall be covered in with 178 rustic.

The roof shall be covered with cedar shingles laid 5 inches to the weather with ridge boards 175 and 176 respectively.

Corner Plankers 1x12. Sides 1x10. Joists 1x6. Corner Boards 1x6 and 1x5 respectively.

Lining

The floor and walls shall be covered with 176 tongue and groove lumber and ceiling with 1/2 x 6 s.s.

Paint

The building shall have two good coats of paint inside and out.

All material shall be landed on the bank of the river at the nearest point adjacent to the...
building and all material shall be furnished by Rev A J Hall who has been authorized by the Dominion Gov't to erect the same.

The contractor shall furnish all labor needed for the erection of the said building and shall do the work in a workmanlike manner.

The contract price for said labor shall be one hundred and twenty dollars ($120).

Signed at Alert Bay

Sir:-

I beg to call your attention to the necessity of erecting a day-school at Gwaya at the head of Kingcome Inlet.

There is a large village of upwards of 300 Indians at this place and about 40 children of school age, we have a school at Gwayasdums where these Indians stay from November to March, but it is most important we should follow them when they go to their summer village at Gwaya.

Five hundred dollars would build a very substantial school.

Permit me also to remind you of a letter received from Ottawa last October containing the following passage:—"The Superintendent General has directed me to insert an item in the Estimates for next year to provide for the maintenance of ten girls at your Home at $60 each per annum each which if passed will be available after the 1st of July next."

I need scarcely say how anxiously I am waiting to be assured that this item has been passed.

This Girls Home has been open thirteen

Sir

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter 498 - V - 4, dated Jan 17th, 1906, asking for a report on the Guysdums Day School Building, &c. I beg to report as follows.

The condition of the building is anything but good; it never was anything but a shell about 50 feet long by about 15 wide, with shake roof. There are two rooms partitioned off at one end used by the Teacher as a residence and which is fairly comfortable; the other half of the building is used for a School room and when I visited it on Jan 25th, it presented anything but an inviting appearance; with a good large heating stove and plenty of fuel, the room could be kept warm in moderately cold weather, but as there was no stove and the pipe hole through the roof let in the rain & fresh air the children certainly needed lots of exercise to enable them to keep warm. I saw Mr Pearson this morning and asked him would the Society under which he teaches agree to insure the use of the building for School purposes for any length of time?, his answer was that he did not know but he supposed so; as a matter of fact Mr Hall who is at the head of the Missionary work here is at present absent in England, and Mr Pearson who has only been here does not know or understand.

I would suggest that instead of spending money on this old rattletrap which can never be made a good building, that a new School house be built costing in the neighborhood of $450.00, part of the old building could be then be torn down and the material used in making the balance of it into a comfortable residence for the teacher.

Mr Pearson seems to be an earnest and painstaking young man who is doing good work considering the way he is handicapped.

I have the honor to be

Sir

Your Obedient Servant

Sir:

I have the honor to inform you that it was brought to my attention that the Indian Day School on the reserve at Kingcome Inlet had fallen off its foundation and was in a dangerous condition and not fit to be used. I immediately went up to investigate and found that the high water during last winter had undermined the posts and the whole building had moved over sideways and was now sitting flat on the ground. It is surprising that no worse damage was done to it as it will not be a very expensive matter to raise it up again. The ground there is sandy and when the river is in freshet it overflows its banks and the current runs swiftly past the building and under it.

I propose to get men to raise it up with jackscrews and under each post put a platform about 3 feet square which platform will be sunk into the ground so that the top of it will be at least six inches under the surface level.

Last week while at Kingcome Inlet I examined the old school building which was built there 26 years ago. Some years ago a very high river washed it off its foundations and racked it very much. I had it raised at that time and put new foundation posts under it and while it was able to be used for some time after it could not be made very much of as the walls could not be plumbed, since then it has gradually got worse and in addition dry rot has set in on the end of the posts and the end of rafters, and it would cost more to put the building right than to build a new one. One of the Indians, George Scow asked me if the Department would be willing to sell him the lumber and he would tear it down and cut it up into various lengths for a small house he intended building. He said he was willing to pay $75.00 for it which I think it is all it is worth and I would recommend it be sold. The nails are rusted nearly off and another storm would demolish it entirely;

Your obedient servant,

Reverend Sir:

I am directed to acknowledge your letter of the 28th ultimo, with enclosures, concerning the cost of the day school at Kingcome Inlet. The accounts you forwarded are hardly satisfactory for the purpose of supporting payment by the Department. The Auditor General demands receipts. I am returning the papers, with the suggestion that you have McLeanman, McFeely & Prior prepare a brief account, recapitulating the business you have had with them, and have it receipted. This should be in duplicate. The other accounts should also be receipted and forwarded to the Department in duplicate, if convenient. Upon receipt of these papers, if in order, the matter will be brought to the attention of Dr. Scott.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Oct. 28, 1929

Mr. James C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General
Ottawa, Ontario

Dear Mr. Scott:

Thank you very much for your letters of October the 9th, 156-11-1, and 156-17-1.

With regard to the latter, I may say that the school has cost us £250.00, much more than I anticipated owing to the fact that the Kingcome River has been acting up for a long time, and made it difficult and expensive to get the materials up the river. However it is all completed now except finishing the interior upper part of the wall, and ceiling.

This I have left in order that the Indians may not feel that the whole is completed, and neglect to give the amount promised, namely £600.00.

We have received from the Bishop of the Diocese, £600.00, and £50.00 as a subscription, and expect to get £50.00 from the Indians. Outside of that we still owe a balance on the building as it stands, of £170.00, and we have also to put heating apparatus and other fittings in.

I am sure you will do your best for us, and I shall be very grateful indeed, as I am in hopes that this school will tend to cure some of the evils that are going on in that village.

Last year there was a death, believed by the Indians to be caused by witchcraft, which has caused a great deal of trouble. I am trying to combat these things, and hope by getting them together in the new school, I'll be able to persuade them of the foolishness of such ideas.

Thanking you in anticipation, I am

Yours faithfully,

John Steele
Supt Columbia Coast Mission.

Ottawa, May 21st, 1930.

Rev. Sir:

Relative to the accounts which you submit covering the cost of the coal supplied for the use of the Kingcome Inlet Indian Day School during the winter 1929-30 to the amount of $574.90, I have to inform you that a cheque in payment of these accounts will be sent you in due course.

The department would favourably consider the supplying of fuel for this school in future. The teacher or yourself should, in due time, forward a request for the quantity and kind of fuel required to the local Indian Agent, Mr. Wm. Halliday, Alert Bay, B.C. We are informing Mr. Halliday accordingly, and requesting him to submit these requests for fuel to the Department, when he will be given authority to arrange for the purchase. The Department prefers that this arrangement be carried out in the supplying of fuel to Indian day schools.

Your obedient servant,

Dr Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Dr Scott,

I am enclosing two small pictures of the new school at Kingcome. It has been completed inside and out, with comfortable quarters overlooking the River. The Indians helped remarkably well and would have done better but were not allowed. The Wakeman Band voted $200.00 towards the building specially for the finishing of the interior of the school. The Columbia Coast Mission was finishing the nurses' quarters, and supplied the Indians with material with the understanding that they would meet the bill with their $200.00. But tho' they sent in letters signed by all the members of the Band and later I was told, Mr Halliday visited the village and vetoed the gift. Said it was contrary to department rules to allow Indians to vote the "interest" for such purposes. I do not know about this, but you will, and I know you will set it right if possible.

I am enclosing fuel bills which we have paid, and which last year you were good enough to say the Department would meet. This probably ought to be sent through Mr Halliday but I find it difficult to deal with him and much more satisfactory to deal direct with the Department.

Trusting you are well,

Sincerely Yours,

[Signature]

P.S. I am glad to report that the Staff of this school, Miss Solomon, Graduate Nurse, and Miss Adams, Deaconess, are doing remarkably fine work.

School Desks:

There are at present in this school 9 Number 4; and 11 Number 3 Crown School Desk Sections. There are no front or rear sections. As arranged at present with a form at the back of the desks seating is available for 20 out of the 35 children. This is for other educational reasons a very bad system. Many of the children are too far from the light. The remaining 15 children are working around a table near the centre of the room, which is very large. They have so little light here that their eyes will no doubt be damaged if this practice is kept up for long. I have no other option but to request the Department to provide the detail of school desks and parts as listed at the bottom of this page. This has all been worked out at the school so as to give the best accommodation at the least cost.

The supply of the following Crown School Desks is very strongly recommended:- 2 Front Sections No. 3 - 2 Rear Sections No. 3. 1 Front Section No. 4 - 1 Rear Section No. 4. 1 Front Section No. 5 - 6 Desk Sections No. 5. 1 Rear Section No. 5; These sections will provide accommodation for 10 children. Dear Sir;

I have received a letter dated September 18, 1932, from Miss Lily K. Solomon with regard to the lack of desks at the Kingcome Inlet Indian Day School. As I was away from my office here till nearly the end of October my answer is dated October 29th. Copies of Miss Solomon's letter and my reply are attached for the information of the Department.

Reference is suggested to my report on the Kingcome Inlet Indian Day School forwarded to your office on April 8th, and which was sent to The Secretary of the Department in Ottawa, under your 15/24605, on that date.

You will note that I reported an attendance of 30 children on the day of my inspection, while there were 35 on the roll of the school, and only 9 Number 4 and 11 Number 3 Crown School Desk Sections giving seating for 20 children.

To overcome this very unsatisfactory condition of affairs, I recommended (Very strongly) the supply of the following:

- 2 Front Sections No.2.
- 2 Rear Sections No.3.
- 1 Front Section No.4.
- 1 Rear Section No.4.
- 1 Front Section No.5.
- 6 Desk Sections No.5.
- and 1 Rear Section No.5.

In my report I showed how these would provide seating for 10 extra children, bringing up the number of available seats to 30 the number of children actually present during the inspection.

The lack of proper seating accommodation near the light may lead to serious eye trouble. The schoolroom which is only a few years old is very badly designed for a schoolroom, as it is intended for use as a church. At the best the system of lighting is very poor.

I beg to recommend that in addition to those Front, Rear, and Desk Sections recommended in my previous report, the following be now supplied to the Kingcome Inlet Indian Day School:

- 1 Front Section No.2.
- 6 Desk Sections No.2.
- 1 Rear Section No.2.

These should be Crown Single School Desks, as manufactured by the Tait Pipe Co. of Vancouver, as the previous desks supplied to this school were of this kind.

If the attendance continues to grow above 40 it will be necessary for some of the children to be sent to a Residential School. The present schoolroom will not accommodate such a number, even if the teacher could handle them.

The above is now a very urgent matter, and my recommendations are placed at a minimum. A Blackboard 12ft. by at least 3½ ft. would also seem to be required to increase the space available for seat work exercises.

Your obedient servant,

GHB
District Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
The school term opened on September 6th with thirteen children present. Many of the Indians have come back since, and last Friday we had twenty-one present. Tomorrow we expect to have at least thirty, as we have now thirty-nine rolls on the roll. I suppose a few will be here in April after the fishing up the river closes. We have all grades up to and including Grade five. We need desks very badly as we have only sixteen at present. The pupils cannot do good work unless they have satisfactory desks. Last week I sent a requisition to Mr. Halliday asking for a dozen desks, but with the number of pupils now enrolled we should have at least two dozen.

I find the blackboard space very limited also. With so many grades it is necessary to put a great deal of seatwork on the blackboards. If one could be placed at the back of the room or between the windows it would help a great deal.

I think that the pupils are doing well & we hope to pass them into higher grades as soon as possible.

Yours sincerely,
Lily K. Solomon.

Miss Lily K. Solomon,
Indian Day School,
Kingcome Inlet, B.C.

Dear Sir,

I request authority for a further expenditure of Thirty Dollars to cover the cost of erection of toilets for use at Kingcome Inlet Day School. This work has not been completed and is still in progress.

One unforeseen contingency in connection with this work is the fact that two weeks ago a somewhat serious flood occurred at Kingcome village, which not only delayed the work, but rendered it necessary to change the type of construction originally decided upon with a view to the possibility of these buildings being carried away in the event of future floods, being obviated. Sir-

Replying to your letter dated November 10 re the above, I have to report that the Kingcome Inlet Indian Day School is conducted in a building which was erected and is owned by the Anglican Diocese of New Westminster. The teacher's residence is also included in the same building.

On my arrival here I found there was a certain amount of confusion in connection with this school. Vouchers for fuel supplies for the school were being submitted to the Columbia Coast Mission and after some delay eventually reached this office, being transmitted by me to the Department in the usual manner for payment. In view of the fact that some payments were outstanding at the close of the fiscal year, this system had to be abandoned and I instructed the teacher to forward these vouchers direct to me.

During his inspection of this school in May last, Capt. G.H. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools for B.C., instructed that windows were to be provided for two sides of the school instead of on the one side, the regulations of the Provincial Department of Education now calling for daylight to be shown from both sides of a schoolroom. By this time I had ascertained that the building was the property of the Church, and I therefore approached His Lordship Archbishop DePencier for the necessary permission to have these other windows provided before writing the Department for authority. However on applying to the Secretary of the Columbia Coast Mission for the dimensions of the building so that the new windows could be uniform with those already fixed, he informed me that he could do nothing in the matter until the return from England of the Rev. John Antis, the Superintendent of the Columbia Coast Mission. Consequently, I have done nothing further in this matter.

There is very definite authority that so long as this building is used for Day School purposes, the Department will supply the fuel, and it is understood that the Department also undertakes the necessary repair work so long as the building is used as a Day School and is the teacher's residence. The situation at present is that the building is not the property of the Department, but of the Church and the only expenditure required for repairing the roof is the cost of one bundle of shingles and the necessary labour. At the present time I cannot quote the price of the shingles as this fluctuates considerably, but the whole cost would not amount to more than a few dollars whereas if this leakage is not repaired as soon as possible, it is probable that the cost of repairing the roof at a future date would be considerably higher. This building is somewhat "jerry-built" but at present it is the only one on the Kingcome Inlet reserve which can be used for school purposes.

Your obedient servant,

E.G. Newnham

Sir:

Replying to your letter of April 7th in which you request if I consider a 6 x 4 blackboard absolutely necessary for the Kingcome Inlet Day School, I wish to point out I have, since receiving your communication, accompanied by Capt. G.H. Barry, Inspector of Schools, visited this school and it was decided this blackboard was necessary for the efficient carrying on of work in this school. In view of this, I would recommend that the Department purchase one black Hyloplate blackboard size 6 x 4'.

I note you also advise that owing to lack of funds, the Department is not prepared to purchase twenty-four desks for this school at the present time. This I am very sorry indeed to learn, because I feel if the Department could see the difficulties under which these children have to be accommodated, I am sure an effort would be made to supply seating facilities. This matter has been reported according to our files, on and off for the past two years; in 1932 the Department requested we bring the matter before them after the end of the fiscal year, and last year this item was put in the Estimates with a strong recommendation that they be supplied.

Since taking over the Agency, my policy has been to curtail all unnecessary expenditure, but this is one case where I feel I must appeal to the Department if it is at all possible to furnish this school with the desks requested. At the present time the children are sitting on packing boxes of all shapes and sizes and the same are being used for desks. I might also point out there are Indian children in this village who are not attending school and it is difficult for me to insist upon them going when they must sit on packing boxes.

I therefore again appeal to you to have these desks furnished this school.

Your obedient servant,

MST/T

BRITISH COLUMBIA,

BABINE AGENCY,

Hazelton, July 21st 1906.

SIR,-

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter 743, X-4, dated the 8th ultimo., stating that in a letter, dated the 1st ibid., received from the Department, attention had been directed to some remarks made by Mr. School Inspector Green, in a recent report of inspection of the Kispiox Indian Day School, and that the remarks were,

to wit:-

"An heathen potlatch and dancing this winter made the attendance smaller than usual. The school would be far better attended if the potlatch was given up."

"No school house. School is held in an Indian house rented by the teacher who pays the rent from his own pocket. A school house is urgently needed in this large village."

"The parents invited me to meet them in council, where they spoke very strongly in favor of a boarding school, etc., etc."

As to the heathen potlatch and dancing, referred to, having made the attendance of children small at that school, I have the honour to state that Mr. Inspector Green was not rightly informed. The Indians of Kispiox, whose children make up the attendance were during last winter chiefly in the woods logging.

In so far as the socalled potlatch is concerned, it was merely a memory feast attended by the old heathens of Kuldoe, Kisgegas and Kitwankool. Really, no objectionable feature is, in my opinion, connected therewith. There is no dancing practised amongst the Indians of this district in any shape, unless the crow-like hopping about of an old Indian, in ancient costume,

A. W. VOWELL, ESQUIRE
Superintendent of Indian Affairs, B.C., &c.
VICTORIA, B.C.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6396, File 819-1, part 1)
can so be termed. If more than one engaged therein, it can be likened to a pantomime not unlike the movements in a minuet performed by ptarmigans, plus the grotesque in array and accompaniment of grunts.

The Indians attending a feast - and I do not think that there will be another for want of patronage - are the old Indians that spend all the year on the hunting ground, and, so far, it remains their sole diversion for about two weeks during the long winter. They are law-abiding and loyal, and seldom ever give evidence of their existence unless when meekly coming in to trade, whereas the precocious, of the paper-collar kind, have constantly their little fires kindled for something to fry.

Regarding the Indian day school building, said by the inspector to be required at Kispiax, I will report upon the same as soon as a plan, in duplicate, can carefully be prepared and properly laid before the Department inclusive concerning incidentals.

In respect to a boarding school, for the same locality, a report from me will likewise be somewhat deferred for the reason stated.

I have the honour to be,

SIR,

Your obedient servant,

GENERAL REMARKS.

Mr. Lee's many duties take a great deal of his time and Mrs. Lee with two little children (one a baby) cannot be expected to give more than the practical lessons.

I would suggest a well qualified teacher be secured, as there is ample work for one to do.

Where the church gives an extra grant over the salary to the missionary to teach the school, there is an inclination to try and do without a teacher and sometimes the school suffers.

Mr. Lee is doing the best he can, but he has not sufficient time for school teaching.

Dear Sir,

A letter has recently come to hand from the Indian School teacher at Kispiz on the Upper Skeena, B.C., accompanying duplicate of school returns for the December quarter. In view of the disturbed condition among the Indians in that part of the country the following extract from the teacher's letter may be of some interest:

"The disturbances, also the continued feasting during the closing weeks of December, reduced the attendances and was disappointing. On the whole the attendances were good considering the very great disadvantages this winter; for some time every eligible child was attending school. The people are very friendly to me personally. I have always had great happiness in the Indian work, and look forward to a continuance.

Kispida Mission
Report for April 1913

The number of visits made this month was fifty-eight.

The last house having had measles patients in it has been fumigated also after a great deal of persuasion. Old Chief Paul's house has been cleaned.

The illnesses in the village this month have included, besides those of recipient or suspected tuberculosis:

8 chronic cases
4 cases sore eyes
3 cases tonsillitis
3 " malnutrition or overstrain
1 " skin disease
1 " rheumatism
2 births and 1 death
The tubercular cases are doing well, finding it easy to be out of doors at this season of the year. Also the women have improved a little regarding the quality of nourishment they give their children. This is shown among heathen and Christian alike in the better nourished bodies of the little ones.

Our accident was that of a girl of ten years playing beside the river. One of the boys, son of a "medicine man," is noted for his roughness and playing there at the same time with others of the village children. The other children had started home, and at last Ellen began to go up the bank also but the boy seizing her arm from behind dragged her down the bank. She did not complain when at home for about a week afterwards when swelling and immobility could hardly be hidden. She was then taken to the...
It was a younger sister of Ellen's who was injured two years ago in an accident which we could never get an account but which was supposed to have been the result of a drunken brawl. From this she never recovered and this month ended a long illness resembling tuberculosis when the little sufferer died.

An Indian Constable came and reported three places where the native liquor was being made after most of it had been drunk. However, the discovery was much to our satisfaction as we had known the

reason is not wholly sufficient

May 27, 1913
Sir,

I have the honor to report that a delegation composed of some of the leading Indians of Kishpiax waited on me at Port Essington, when I was there this month. They requested me to state their wishes to the Department regarding the Day School at Kishpiax, Babine Agency. They wish a teacher to teach the Day School separate from the missionary.

They stated that the Rev. R.W. Lee, Missionary and teacher for the past two years has now left the village and Agency, and Miss. Richardson, the nurse, who did a good work has gone to Alberta, so they are without anyone. They claim that when it is left with the missionary to teach the school, the school is not properly cared for.

I consider the Indians have ample cause to complain of the way the school has been conducted of late. If a missionary does his work properly he will be a busy man in this large village. And if a teacher does his work well, with fifty-nine children of school age in the village and forty-three enrolled, there is sufficient work in the school for nine months of the year for any one person however well qualified.

These people are very anxious for their children to be taught and when a suitable teacher, like Miss. Klippert (now at Metlakatla) and Miss. Kemp (now teacher at Kitwanga), who formerly taught this school, were the teachers, the children attended well, made progress and the parents were satisfied.

The Rev. R.W. Lee received a salary of $800.00, $500.00 of this being the grant from the Department to the Methodist Missionary Society for the school, this being supplemented by $300.00 from the Missionary Society. Mr. Lee was expected to do and did, missionary
among the whites, and was often away from the Indian village.

The school has not received fair treatment the past year, and the Indians are afraid the same may happen again.

I would respectfully but strongly recommend that the church authorities be commissioned with an order that a suitable teacher be secured for the coming September, who shall give proper attention to the school. It would be more satisfactory, with a good teacher giving full time to the school, to increase the salary a hundred dollars, than to give the present grant, and the work for it not being properly done, hence the salary unearned.

I have the honor to remain

Your obedient servant

Inspector.

REMARKS.

The whole situation here is discouraging. The people are apathetic, both as regards their religious state and the education of their children.

The presence on the reserve of two pool rooms seems to me to be a disgrace, especially as the children are in there until all hours of the night. Dancing and card playing are all in vogue and the people are deteriorating. The children are not dull and could progress if attendance was enforced.

I am informed by the Rev. T. H. Wright, United Church Minister at Hazelton, that Miss Helen Earl may be removed from Kispiox in the near future.

As Indian Agent, I have been in constant touch with Miss Earl and I wish to call your kind attention to the great service Miss Earl has rendered to the adults besides the children of Kispiox.

Miss Earl is doing particularly good work at Kispiox. Her children at the school are well advanced in their studies and the school ranks very high amongst the schools of this Agency. Through her untiring efforts in helping the Indians, both young and old, Miss Earl has endeared herself to the Natives.

Dear Sir:

Re: Kispiox Indian Day School.

The Indians at Kispiox have been agitating for a number of years for a missionary-teacher. The British Columbia Conference at its recent session nominated Rev. J. T. Burchill, M.A., who has been supplying at Port Essington during the past year, for that position.

Mr. Burchill is a Master of Arts of Dublin University and was for a number of years a missionary in Honduras. He has been in British Columbia for five or six years and has taught successfully in Columbian College, New Westminster, and a private school for boys. I do not know whether his certificate would be accepted by the British Columbia Department of Education or not. There is a letter from him today in which he expresses himself as willing to spend July and August mastering the curriculum of the public schools in British Columbia. The fact that he conducted a very successful night school in Port Essington last year would seem to indicate that he has the ability to teach elementary subjects. He has a wife and three children and is desirous of moving to Kispiox on the 1st July, if his nomination as teacher of the day school is satisfactory to the Department.

I have not met Mr. Burchill personally, but Dr. Barner, our Superintendent of Indian Missions, visited him in Port Essington and was very favorably impressed.

I sincerely trust that this nomination will meet with the favor of the Department and that the salary allowed will at least be as much as Miss Earl was receiving.

Yours very sincerely,

Kenneth J. Beaton

Dear Mr. Hansen:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of July 30th and also certain correspondence relating to the dismissal of Reverend J. T. Burchill from the Kispiox Indian Day School, enclosed therewith.

The records here indicate that Mr. Burchill was appointed teacher at the Kispiox Day School on June 25th, 1934, and was nominated for the position by the then Associate Secretary of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada. The appointment was made for the academic year 1934-35.

It was noted by the Department at that time that Mr. Burchill had no professional certificate recognized as valid in Canada, nor had he any previous experience in teaching at an Indian day or residential school.

Inspector Barry's first report on his work at the Kispiox School is dated September 18th, 1935. Mr. Barry, in this report, expresses the opinion that Mr. Burchill was rather erratic in a temperamental sense and very severe in his discipline. Mr. Burchill admitted to the Inspector at that time that he used the strap frequently. The Inspector, however, was anxious that this teacher should be given an opportunity to make good, and his specific recommendation to the Department was that a close check be kept on the actions of the teacher during the year.

The next report of the Inspector on this school is dated September 15th, 1936. The Inspector, at that time,

was profoundly

Olof Hansen, Esq., M.P.,
Smithers,
B.C.
was profoundly dissatisfied with the progress of the pupils and expressed the opinion that Mr. Burchill was in a very nervous condition and, in his judgment, on the verge of a physical breakdown. In view of these facts, the Inspector recommended that the United Church authorities be asked to replace Mr. Burchill at the earliest possible moment.

The Acting Superintendent of Indian Education wrote at that time to the Associate Secretary of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada, sending forward to him a copy of Captain Barry's report. The Secretary's reply is dated October 15th, 1936, and, in this letter, the Secretary states:

"I appreciate the trouble which you have taken to copy Inspector Barry's report concerning the recent inspection of the Kispiox Indian Day School. I am inclined to think that, for once, Mr. Barry is absolutely right; but you are well aware of the great difficulty we have in securing men of the right type for that particular school. I do not believe that anything can be done about it before June 30th."

Inspector Barry's next report is dated May 25th, 1937. In this report, the Inspector states:

"The teacher was ill with nerves in May and June, 1936, and was granted sick leave. He was absent from the school at the time of this inspection and I did not see him.

There is nothing on record here to indicate that Mr. Burchill obtained permission to leave his school at that time, from the Department, the local Indian Agent or the office at Victoria.

In his recommendations, the Inspector takes a strong stand that, in the interests of the school and in the interests of Mr. Burchill, himself, a change of teacher at Kispiox should be given careful consideration by the Department.

The subject
The subject matter of the Inspector's reports has been discussed, by letter and personally, with the United Church authorities. The Associate Secretary of the Home Mission Board took the position very definitely, when the matter was last discussed with him, that so far as he was personally concerned, he was prepared to abide by the recommendations contained in the Inspector's report. He had in mind at that time not only the Inspector's report on the Kispox School but other reports, the subject matter of which had been brought to his attention at that time.

It is just possible that a great deal of the difficulty has arisen as the result of Mr. Burchill's physical condition. In a letter addressed to him dated April 25th, 1936, Dr. H. C. Winch, of Hazelton, states:

"I am of the opinion that, in order to avoid what might be a very serious nervous breakdown, it is advisable that you arrange with as little delay as possible to take from six to eight weeks of rest and entire relaxation."

Mr. Burchill objects, as I understand it, not so much to his dismissal but rather to the procedure followed by the departmental officials with respect to his dismissal. I may state, by way of comment, that it has never been the policy or practice of the Department to supply teachers in charge of our Indian day or residential schools with copies of Inspectors' reports. These reports are very carefully prepared candid documents, and have always been looked upon by the Department as strictly confidential. Provincial Departments of Education have learned from experience that an adverse or critical Inspector's report supplied to a teacher frequently militates against, rather than contributes to, his or her success in a school. British Columbia may be an exception, but the Departments of Education in most of the Provinces do not supply teachers with copies of Inspectors' reports. Copies, however, are sent to Secretaries of Trustee Boards. Inspector Barry is one of our senior officials, particularly well qualified to pass judgment.
judgment on the work of a teacher. He occupies a very exacting position and is called upon to work in close cooperation with the church authorities, the teachers in charge of schools, the Indian population and the general public. I am convinced that, in his recommendations from year to year, he is actuated by no motives other than a desire to see capable, fully qualified and successful teachers in charge of the schools for the progress of which he is responsible.

Mr. Burchill, in paragraph 11 of his reply to Mr. Oostehout's letter of October 26th, 1936, refers to Indian Agent Mortimer and to his alleged hostility to the teacher from the time of his first arrival at the school, and states:

"It is clear that Captain Mortimer wants a lady teacher at Kispiox and has gone so far as to offer the school to Miss Tretiak several times lately."

Mr. Burchill should know that the Department has never at any time permitted Indian agents to nominate teachers for Indian day schools, and this also applies to Captain Barry. These appointments are made at all times by the Department and the Department accepts full responsibility for the appointments when they are made. In the case of the Kispiox and a number of other schools, we extend to the United Church an opportunity to nominate teachers for any positions that may be vacant, but the Department has never felt itself bound to accept such nominations. We frequently insist that two or three names be submitted in the case of a vacancy, so that the officials may have an opportunity to pass judgment on the qualifications and fitness of the applicants.

I do not know that there is much that I can add to the views I have already expressed. Reference has been made to Mr. Burchill's health. In addition to this, he appears to be a very highly strung, temperamental and somewhat erratic individual. It is just possible that while he may be eminently qualified for educational work
in an advanced school, he did not find the work at Kispiox sufficiently challenging. It is significant and worthy of note that we have experienced a great deal of difficulty the last two or three years with male teachers who have been given positions at elementary Indian day schools. The average male teacher seems to lack the necessary powers of adaptability for this work. On the other hand, female teachers, with the same or lower qualifications, are, with very rare exceptions, outstandingly successful.

I want to thank you very heartily for the courtesy that prompted you to bring this matter to my personal attention.

I am returning herewith the correspondence enclosed with your communication.

Yours very truly,

Dear Dr. Dorey:

There is a strong feeling on the part of our workers on the Upper Skeena that there should be two teachers at Kispiox and I believe that is felt by others who are related to the education of the Indians in the North.

Miss Doris Bews as you know has been supplying there for a few months and has given excellent service. Mr. More has volunteered as a teacher for that school in conjunction with the work of the Mission and at my request he visited the field recently. While he is not endeavouring to escape any of the work involved in the school teaching he feels that to do justice to 66 students with a prospective addition of a dozen more in September that he should have an assistant, otherwise he says it will be quite impossible to retain the interest of the more advanced grades.

In order to do this, it will be necessary for the Department to add another room to the present building and I believe the Indian Agent has suggested that the wood-shed might be utilized with some alterations for that purpose. Would you be good enough to take the matter up with the Department at Ottawa, to see if as an emergency case they could provide the small amount necessary for this added accommodation.

I am sure it will give fine results if both Miss Bews and Mr. More can be retained as teachers in Kispiox where there is already awakened a keener interest on the part of the children and also on the part of their parents than has been manifested for many years.

Dear Dr. Dorey:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 25th ultimo, in which you seek information with respect to the policy of the Department in providing living accommodation for Indian day school teachers.

The records here indicate that it is not the policy of the Department to provide living accommodation for teachers, and no living accommodation has been provided on a number of the reserves in eastern Canada. It has been our policy recently, however, to provide living quarters when constructing schools on isolated reserves or on reserves where teachers may find it impossible to secure board and lodging. In a number of cases the teacher acts as missionary and in such cases living accommodation is invariably provided by the church. As a rule salaries are not influenced by living accommodation or lack of living accommodation. The experience of the teacher, the enrolment at the school, its accessibility, etc., are all factors that are usually reviewed by the Department before the salary of the teacher is decided upon.

Yours sincerely,

REPORT ON BABINE AGENCY FOR MONTH OF JANUARY, 1943.

SCHOOLS

Due to the extremely cold weather during a good part of the month - ranging from 20 to 45 degrees below zero - many pupils have been sick, and the attendance at some of the day schools has been small. The schools visited were: Hazelton, Glen Vowell and Kitsegukla. Mrs. Amyot, teacher of the Moricetown Day School, is still in the Wrinnon Memorial Hospital, Hazelton, having been dangerously ill since January 3. Consequently, Moricetown Day School has been closed throughout the month of January. Miss Pearson, teacher of the junior room at Kispiox, has been away from school one week, suffering from pleurisy.

Dear Major MacKay:

Last evening I was in Hazelton taking part in a Thanksgiving service, following which strong and urgent representations were made regarding the school. It is too bad that so many children are running around without any teaching being done.

Our minister at Hazelton, and his wife, have made an offer which is worth serious consideration. They are prepared to move out to Kispiox right away and to open one room as soon as arrangements can be made to do so. If there seems need of the second room being opened, they would also undertake that at the beginning of either December or January. It is to be understood that teaching is to be on the basis of four days a week, Tuesday to Friday, inclusive, and that when our annual Conference meets in May, they will be free to attend. For this they would expect to be paid four-fifths of the usual salary, plus bonus and whatever else may have gone with the salary at that school.

I discussed the plan with Mr. Boys, Indian Agent, and he will be writing you giving his approval.

Our minister's name is Rev. R.C.B. Morris. He is about 25 years of age and a graduate of U.B.C. Mrs. Morris is a few years younger, a Vancouver girl with Grade 12 standing. Both of them have had wide experience in Vacation School work and Young People's Leadership, are musical and greatly devoted to making a contribution to our Indian mission work. I have no hesitation in recommending the appointment, on a temporary basis, of Mrs. Morris to the school, and if necessary, later on would make a similar recommendation re Mr. Morris. If the proposal meets with your approval, would you communicate direct with your Department and with Dr. Dorsey, as I may not reach my office before Early November.

I want to repeat, that I am not asking the Department to change its policy re employment of only certificated teachers. I am merely passing on to you what I consider a splendid offer for help in an emergency, and will abide by your decision.

W.P.B.

Most sincerely yours,

Kispiox two roomed school would have been closed but for the United Church missionary's wife, Mrs. Morris, jumping into the breach four days a week and so far as can be judged did an excellent job.
