8. Dependents. Taxpayers may claim as dependents only:

(1) A person wholly dependent on the taxpayer for support and of whom the taxpayer has, or immediately before such person attained the age of twenty-one years had, in law or in fact, the custody and control.

(2) Sons and daughters (including illegitimate sons and daughters) or sons-in-law or daughters-in-law, brothers and sisters or brothers-in-law or sisters-in-law, and grandchildren, if under eighteen years of age, or under twenty-one and attending school, or over eighteen years of age and incapable of self-support.

(3) Parents of grandparents, parents-in-law, or grandparents-in-law, incapable of self-support.

(4) A daughter or sister under twenty-one years of age, training as a nurse in a public or provincially operated hospital.

9. If Child under 16 and not Registrable for Family Allowances. A taxpayer may claim an exemption of only $100 for each child dependent child that was not yet have been registered under The Family Allowances Act, 1944, so that an allowance under the said Act was or might be claimed paid in respect of the last year of the taxation year. With a few exceptions, every child under 16 years of age may be registered and receive payments under The Family Allowances Act. Therefore, Form T.D.I. provides for the $100 exemption claimed for each dependent shown in Item 5 as having been born after November 1931.

There are isolated cases, however, of children under 16 years of age who are not registrable for family allowances. An employee supporting such a dependent child is entitled to claim the $300 exemption for tax deduction purposes. Therefore, an employee receiving a T.D.I. form in which the employee claims the $300 exemption of a child under 16 years of age may make deductions accordingly but he must immediately refer the T.D.I. form to the District Inspector of Income Tax for confirmation, accompanied by a declaration signed by the employee outlining the facts which substantiate his claim that he is the sole supporter of a child who is not eligible for registration under The Family Allowances Act.

10. If Income of Spouse in Excess of $250. A taxpayer is not entitled to claim married status if his (her) spouse will have an income of more than $750 during the calendar year. If the spouse will have an income of more than $250 but not more than $750, the exemption permitted for marital status may be reduced by the amount by which the income of the spouse exceeds $250 (e.g., if the spouse's income will be—say $600, then $350 should be entered in Item 6(B) (2) (i.e., $600 less $250). If the spouse's own income is less than $250, Item 6(B) (2) will be left blank and the full marital exemption of $750 entered in Item 6(B) (3).

11. "Self-contained Domestic Establishment" means a dwelling house, apartment or other similar place of residence, containing at least two bedrooms, in which residence amongst other things the taxpayer as a general rule lives and has his meals prepared and served. See Item 10.

12. Change in Status or Dependents. If during the year any change occurs in the status or dependents of an employee, the employee must report and file with his return an amended Form T.D.I.

(Revised for Jan. 1947) is not completed and filed with the employer, deductions from the employee's wages and salary after January 1st, 1947 must be treated as if the employee were a single person without dependents even though the employee may have filed a previous Form T.D.I. Single persons without dependents need not file.

14. Filing of Income Tax Return. In addition to filing this form you must file your income Tax Return Form T.T. Special or T.T. General for the calendar year on or before 30th April of the following year.

INSTRUCTIONS TO THE EMPLOYER

15. If Form T.D.I Not Filed By Employee. Any employee who fails to file a completed Form T.D.I. (Revised for Jan. 1947) must be regarded for tax deduction purposes as a single person without dependents and deductions made as per column 1 in the Table of Income Tax Deductions (1947).

16. Employer to Scrutinize Claim by Single Person for Married Status. The term "Self-contained Domestic Establishment" contained in Item 11 indicates clearly that a taxpayer is not entitled to claim Married Status by reason of supporting a dependent within which the dependent actually resides with the taxpayer. Therefore, employers are instructed to check the address shown under Item 4(B) or 4(D) with the taxpayer's own address in Item 5 (which should show where he is actually living at the time of making the declaration) and in every case where the addresses are not the same the employer must make deductions as if the taxpayer were a single person, with or without dependents as the case may be.

17. Employer's Responsibility Regarding Form T.D.I. The employer will have regard to the instructions contained in Item 11 and will check the employee's completion of the total exemptions in Item 6 and will otherwise make certain that the form is fully completed. He will also delete as a dependent under Item 5 the name of any person whose employment has already been listed in Item 4 unless the claim for Married status came within paragraph (B) thereof. If the employer has reason to believe that any of the information on the form is incorrect or incomplete he must make the necessary correction until the employee has made the appropriate confirmation or correction. In case of doubt the matter should be referred to the District Inspector of Income Tax.

18. Action upon Receipt of Amended Form T.D.I. During Currency of Year. Employers are required to file an amended Form T.D.I. if any change occurs in status or dependents. The employer should give immediate effect to a change from "Single" status to "Married" status as a result of marriage in the number of dependents. A change from "Married" status to "Single" status (e.g., where the employee becomes a widower) should not be made effective until the employee pays the tax due for the year because the employee will still be entitled to claim "Married" status for the whole of the calendar year in which the change took place. Similarly, a decrease in the number of dependents should not generally result in a change in the deductions until the following calendar year with one important exception due to the provision that a taxpayer may not claim as a dependent any person who has an income in excess of $400 during the calendar year. If, for example, a son who was previously supported by an employee and was claimed as a dependent on Form T.D.I. takes employment from which he will earn over $400 during the calendar year immediate effect should be given to the amended form T.D.I. as otherwise the employee will be left with a substantial balance of tax to pay with his return on Form T.T. Special or T.T. General.

8. Dependents. Taxpayers may claim as dependents only:

(A) A person wholly dependent on the taxpayer for support and of whom the taxpayer has, or immediately before such person attained the age of twenty-one years did have, in law or in fact, the care, custody, and control.

(B) Sons and daughters (including illegitimate sons and daughters) or sons-in-law or daughters-in-law, brothers and sisters or brothers-in-law or sisters-in-law, or children under eighteen years of age, or under twenty-one and attending school, or over eighteen years of age and incapable of self-support.

(C) Parents, grandparents, parents-in-law, or grandparents-in-law, incapable of self-support.

(D) A daughter or sister under twenty-one years of age training as a nurse in a public or provincially licensed private hospital.

9. If Child Under 16 and Not Registrable for Family Allowances. A taxpayer may claim an exemption of only $100 for a wholly dependent child who must be brought up under The Family Allowances Act, 1944, so that an allowance under the said Act was or might have been paid in respect of the last year of the taxation year. Under certain exceptions, even children under 16 years of age may be registered and receive payments under The Family Allowances Act. Therefore, Form T.D.1 provides that only the $100 exemption shall be claimed for a child entered in Item 5 as having been born after November 1931.

There are isolated cases, however, of children under 16 years of age who are not registrable for family allowances. An employer supporting such a dependent child is entitled to claim the $250 exemption for tax deduction purposes. Therefore, an employer receiving a T.D.1 form in which an employee claims the $300 exemption for a child under 16 years of age may make deductions accordingly but he must immediately refer the T.D.1 form to the District Inspector of Income Tax for confirmation, accompanied by a declaration signed by the employee outlining the facts which substantiate his claim that he is the father, mother, or child who is not eligible for registration under The Family Allowances Act.

10. If Income of Spouse in Excess of $250. A taxpayer is not entitled to claim Married Status if his (her) spouse will have an income of more than $750 during the calendar year. If the spouse will have an income of more than $250 but not more than $750, the exemption permitted for married status must be reduced by the amount by which the spouse's income will exceed $250 (e.g., if the spouse's income will be—say—$600, then $350 should be entered in Item (B) (2) (i.e., $600 less $250). If the spouse's own income for the calendar year will be not more than $250, Item (B) (2) will be left blank and the full marital exemption of $750 entered in Item (B) (3).

11. "Self-contained Domestic Establishment" means a dwelling house, apartment or other similar place of residence, containing at least two bedrooms, in which residence amongst other things the taxpayer has his general rule of sleep and has his meals prepared and served. See Item 16.

12. Change in Status or Dependents. If during the year any change occurs in the status or dependents of an employee, the employee must complete and file with his employer an amended Form T.D.1.

13. Effect of Failure to File Form T.D.1. In cases where Form T.D.1 (Revised for Jan. 1947) is not completed and filed with the employer, deductions from all claims made on or after January 1st, 1947 must be made as if the employee were a single person without dependents even though the employee may have filed a previous Form T.D.1. Single persons without dependents need not file this form.

14. Filing of Income Tax Return. In addition to filing this form you must file your Income Tax Return Form T.I. Special or T.I. General for the calendar year on or before 30th April following the following year.

15. If Form T.D.1 Not Filed by Employee. Any employee who fails to file a completed Form T.D.1 (Revised for Jan. 1947) must be regarded for tax deduction purposes as a single person without dependents and therefore as per column 1 in the Table of Income Tax Deductions (1947).

16. Employer to Scrutinize Claims by Single Persons for Married Status. The definition of a "Self-contained Domestic Establishment" contained in Item 11 must be clearly stated if a taxpayer is not entitled to claim Married Status by reason of supporting a dependent therein unless the dependent actually resides with the taxpayer. Therefore, employers are directed to scrutinize the addresses under Item (E) (a) or (d), with the taxpayer's own address in Item 2 (which should show where he is actually living at the time of making the declaration) to see whether there is any indication that the same the employer must make deductions as if the taxpayer were a single person, with or without dependents as the case may be.

17. Employer's Responsibility Regarding Form T.D.1. The employer will have regard to the instructions contained in Item 16 above, will check the employee's computation of the total exemptions in Item 6 and will otherwise make certain that the form is fully completed. He will also delete as a dependent under Item 5 the name of any person whom the employee has already listed in Item 4 unless the claim for married status is within paragraph (B) (ii). If the employer has reason to believe that any of the information on this form is incorrect or false, he will not act upon the declaration until the employee has made the necessary corrections thereto. In case of doubt, the matter should be referred to the District Inspector of Income Tax.

18. Action upon Receipt of Amended Form T.D.1 during Currency of Year. Employees are required to file an amended Form T.D.1 if any change occurs in status or dependents. The employer should give immediate effect to a change from "Single" status to "Married" status and to an increase in the number of dependents. A change from "Married" status to "Single" status (e.g., where an employee becomes a divorcé) should not be made effective until the first pay period in the next calendar year because the employee will still be entitled to claim "Married" status for the whole of the calendar year in which the change took place. Similarly, a decrease in the number of dependents should not generally require a change in the deductions until the following calendar year with one important exception, namely, to avoid providing that a taxpayer may not claim as a dependent any person who has an income in excess of $400 during the calendar year. If, for example, a son who was previously supported as a dependent and has continued as a dependent on Form T.D.1 takes up employment from which he will earn over $400 during the calendar year, immediate effect should be given to the amended form T.D.1 so that the employer will be left with a substantial balance of tax to pay with his return on Form T.I Special or T.I General.

Dear Doctor Dorey:

Kispiox Indian Day School

Inspector Davey makes the following comments about Miss Currie in his inspector's report dated May 27th, on the above school:

"The discipline in this room is poor. The pupils show little respect for the teacher and this has reduced considerably whatever progress the pupils might have made during the five months this teacher has been in charge. These problems in discipline arise from the failure of the teacher to supply the pupils with sufficient work to keep their time fully occupied, from her personality which fails to command the respect of the pupils, and from her unsuitable methods of punishment.

"There is a considerable lack of books, particularly reading material. This is due to the same reasons that are to be found in the other class of this school; poor mail service, non-receipt of the first copy of the Bulletin, and the fact that this teacher did not take over this class until January of this year.

"The reading of most of the pupils is poor and many of them are attempting material which is too difficult for them. A more varied and more extensive language programme is greatly needed in this school. This teacher lacks initiative in developing the language work."

On the other hand, Mrs. Robert Morris who is teaching in the other room on a five day per week basis is doing a satisfactory job and Inspector Davey is pleased with her efforts.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6396, File 819-1, part 2)
In his covering letter, Major Mackay intimates that the services of Miss Currie have not been satisfactory at this school any more than they were at Port Simpson Indian Day School last year. He has recommended that you be advised that we do not consider her a suitable person to teach in Indian day schools.

Therefore, we would request that you nominate a qualified teacher to replace her and also one for the junior room at Kispiox. It is understood that Mrs. Morris will be leaving the district and that her services will not be available next year.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Oct. 12th 1914

Dear Mr. Loring -

I am sorry to again trouble you re. matter of salary for this quarter. On thinking it over I am greatly worried and hope you will not mind me explaining my position more fully.

I came on to Kootenay as soon as possible after receiving the appointment. The journey was quite an expense ($140), but with the understanding that my salary was to be $578. I borrowed the amount from a friend hoping to refund it within the year. Then I thought it best to send something home to my mother, as things are very slack because of the war. But should I loose this quarter, I shall have very little when my board is paid.

Please forgive me if I am wrong in expecting it, but it seems hard to lose all for the absence of fourteen school days, when the delay was unavoidable.

Thanking you for kindly attention already shown,

Very sincerely,

Gertrude Martin

Reverend Sir,

The Department is in receipt of the following letter from Mr. J.L. Sansum, Teacher of the Kispiox Indian Day School:

"As I intend to make a brief visit to England this summer, and have only limited means, so that I must obtain every dollar that is due me, I wondered if you would do me the favour to forward my summer term cheque slightly in advance. I intend to leave Hazelton on the 24 June, and would like to receive my cheque by the 20th June.

I trust you will find it convenient to render me this service."

As you are aware the salary of the above teacher is paid to the Treasurer of the Methodist Missionary Society.

I should be pleased if you would arrange to forward Mr. Sansum his June quarter cheque so that he will receive it by June 20th and we will forward our cheque, in due course, to the Treasurer.

The last remittance to Mr. Sansum was sent on April 16th, 1926. It was for $235.00. He has previously been paid $665.00. This makes a total of $900.00, which is the salary in full for which he was entitled for the year 1925-26.

Ottawa, July 8, 1929.

Reverend Sir:

With further reference to your general letter of the 25th ultimo, nominating teachers for the Indian day schools under the United Church, I regret to state that the Department can give but temporary approval for the appointment of Miss Helen Earl at the Kispiox Indian Day School. It is my opinion that Miss Earl would make a good field matron or social worker on an Indian reserve; but her qualifications for the classroom exercises are such, that I would urge you to transfer her to other work at the first opportunity. The Kispiox School is a fairly important activity, with a good enrolment, and I consider a strong teacher should be named for the post. The Department approves of the temporary appointment of Miss Earl, at a salary of $90 per teaching month - her duties to commence on September first, next.

Ottawa, May 6, 1936.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 9th ultimo, the Department understands that Rev. J. T. Burchill, teacher of the Kispiox Indian Day School, will be absent from the school, through illness, for the balance of the academic year, and that Miss Westman will take over his duties without cost to the Department.

In view of Rev. Mr. Burchill's condition, this arrangement is approved, but you should point out to him on his return, as well as to the teachers of the other Indian day schools in your Agency, that the schools should not be kept open during holidays or Saturdays without the express permission of the Department. The instructions contained in the circular issued yearly regarding the dates of opening and closing of Indian day schools should be adhered to strictly, unless special permission has been obtained from the Department to deviate from the regulations that are contained in the circular.

Sir,

I had the honour & pleasure of meeting you on board the "Princess Beatrice" in August last. Since that time I have had it on my mind to write you a few facts regarding these Kiskissick Indians. They are a hard working & industrious people very anxious to improve and learn anything that will help them in living a civilized life. I have been their missionary here for ten years and know what I speak. During these ten years we have carried on a day school and have received a grant from the government each year. But this school has been carried on under great difficulties. We have had no school house and have had to rent an Indian house from time to time changing about. For this I have had to pay rent out of my own pocket. The children have attended well & studied hard, but you can readily see that it is impossible to make any progress that should be made if taught under present conditions. There are somewhere about sixty children.
of school age. All of these have not attended owing to their heathen life & potlatch. Since the attendance has been good - the highest average for any quarter being 29-45. Now the potlatch has died a natural death & we expect no more trouble from that source. In fact the heathen are anxious that their children should learn.

A few years ago we asked the government for a grant towards building a school house & they refused. Later I asked the government through Mr. Soring, Indian agent to pay school rent & refund what I had already paid out. That too was refused. Just one year ago asked, grant for a school house was again asked. So far no word has been received either for or against while the government has been so liberal in building school house for other tribes we have been left without all these years, and our people are beginning to feel it keenly. My purpose in writing these to you Sir, is to let you know just exactly how we stand. Wishing you every success in your important & responsible position.

Ottawa, April 7, 1908.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

In compliance with your directions that I should look carefully into the correspondence relating to the Kishpian school to see what can or ought to be done there, I beg to say that, from Mr. Inspector Green's last report on this school, which was made on May 6, 1907, it would appear that a new building is urgently needed. The Indians are anxious to have a boarding school and are willing to give a site on the reserve and all the assistance they can to make a success of it. There are said to be 50 children of school age and Mr. Green gives it as his opinion that a boarding school at this large village would be very beneficial.

The day school at this point has been in operation for a number of years under the auspices of the Methodist Church and is in receipt of the usual salary grant of $300. It has been carried on under difficulties, owing to their never having been provided with a school building, and it was to obtain a grant for this purpose that the Rev. Mr. Pearce, the resident Missionary, applied to the Department two years ago, when he was told that, until the report which Mr. Agent Loring had been
asked to furnish was received, no action could be taken by the Department. After that Mr. Losing sent in a plan of a proposed building with a specification of the material required, which showed that it would cost about $600 to complete a building suitable for the purpose.

A note was made for this year's estimates but, as there has been no additional provision made for British Columbia.

They have an enrolment at this school of 53, with an attendance for December quarter, last, of 31.

It seems to me that the school is entitled to encouragement and that a building should be provided, if possible, and that there is no necessity for a boarding school at that point, and Mr. Inspector Conroy, who travelled through this part of British Columbia last fall, agreed with me in this.

The Secretary,

With reference to the letter from Rev. Mr. Pierce, addressed to the Minister, on the subject of the Indian school at Kispiox, B.C., I beg to say that two years ago Mr. Pierce asked to be allowed to incur an expenditure of $30 for six months' rental for a building in which to carry on the school. In reply to this application the Indian Superintendent at Victoria was informed that it should have come through the proper channel (The Superintendent of Methodist Missions in British Columbia), it being an exceptional case, as the Department was not in the habit of paying rent for schools or putting up shacks buildings for day schools conducted by religious denominations in British Columbia.

Nothing more was heard from Mr. Pierce on this subject nor was any application made by the Superintendent of Methodist Missions, but Mr. School Inspector Green in his report on this school stated that a school-house was urgently needed, as there was none at Kispiox, the school being held in an Indian house rented by the teacher at his own expense. On receipt of this report the Superintendent was asked to make enquiries into this and other matters referred to by the Inspector, and on June 8, last, the Superintendent wrote the Department stating that the matter of the school building required for the Kispiox Indians will be brought to the attention of Mr. Agent Letting, so that he may report fully thereon for the Department's information. There has been no time to receive a reply from Mr. Letting, and the matter is still in abeyance.

I am enclosing you an estimate of a School house for Kispiax Indians. The need of a suitable building is very urgent.
